headline: Morning Agenda: Speedy Start-Up Financing
abstract: Speedy Start-Up Financing | Central Bank and I.M.F. Loom Over Greece Talks | DTZ to Buy Cushman & Wakefield for $2 Billion | China Cuts Benchmark Rate
lead_paragraph: SPEEDY START-UP FINANCING | Uber’s most recent fund-raising talks are notable not just for the $50 billion valuation that would come with a $1.5 billion round of financing, but also for amount of time that has lapsed in between rounds — just five months. Uber and other start-ups have been raising money at a pace that is unprecedented in Silicon Valley, “driven by money pouring in from hedge funds, strategic investors and more, and by the willingness of entrepreneurs to embrace the cash,” Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced write in The New York Times. Mark Suster, a partner at the venture capital firm Upfront Ventures, said there’s only one reason these companies are raising money so quickly: Because they can. “When capital markets are this loose, people tap them, whether it’s right to or not,” he said.

headline: Morning Agenda: 2 Banks Agree to Erase Zombie Debts
abstract: 2 Banks Agree to Erase Zombie Debts | Syngenta Rejects Monsanto’s $45 Billion Bid | Jonathan Steinberg’s Rebirth | British Pound and Stocks Gain on Election Results
lead_paragraph: 2 BANKS AGREE TO ERASE ZOMBIE DEBTS  | Some of the nation’s biggest banks have come under fire for keeping debts alive on credit reports even when they were discharged in bankruptcy, essentially forcing borrowers to make payments on bills that they do not legally owe, as Jessica Silver-Greenberg of DealBook reported last year. Relief may finally be at hand for the consumers whose discharged debts have kept them from getting jobs or renting apartments, now that Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase have agreed to update borrowers’ credit reports within the next three months to reflect that the debts were extinguished, Ms. Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook.

headline: Winner in Race Among Bitcoin Exchanges
abstract: Chad Cascarilla, the chief executive of itBit, on becoming the first Bitcoin exchange allowed to open legally to customers across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Chad Cascarilla, the chief executive of itBit, on becoming the first Bitcoin exchange allowed to open legally to customers across the United States.

headline: Bitcoin Exchange Receives First License in New York State
abstract: The exchange, itBit, said it was taking on customers after receiving a banking trust charter from Benjamin Lawsky, the state’s financial regulator.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s top financial regulator has granted the first license to a Bitcoin exchange, allowing it to open legally to customers across the country.

headline: Morning Agenda: Britain’s Conservatives Get Hedge Funds’ Vote
abstract: Britain’s Conservatives Get Hedge Funds’ Vote | Private Equity’s Hidden Fees | A Wrap-Up of ‘Woodstock for Capitalists’
lead_paragraph: BRITAIN’S CONSERVATIVES GET HEDGE FUNDS’ VOTE | The British elections are on Thursday, and members of one constituency, the financiers, have already made their preference extremely clear, Danny Hakim writes in DealBook. Britain’s Conservative-led government has been a staunch supporter of hedge funds and banks, battling at home and in the European Union on their behalf, and some hedge fund managers have written “eye-popping checks” to the party. More than $2.3 million came from Michael Hintze, an Australian billionaire who lives in London, where he founded the hedge fund CQS; Michael Farmer, another hedge fund manager, has donated roughly $2.2 million over the same reporting period; and Stanley Fink, who once ran the Man Group and has been party treasurer, has donated $1.3 million since the 2010 election.

headline: Bitcoin Comes Out of the Shadows and Into Wall Street’s Sights
abstract: Why Goldman’s investment in a Bitcoin start-up is a sign of a pivotal change.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a panel discussion at the Inside Bitcoins conference in New York this week – billed as the largest such event in the world – a supporter of the cryptocurrency pointed to one of the three lawyers discussing Bitcoin’s struggle for mainstream acceptance.

headline: Morning Agenda: Salesforce Said to be Preparing for Takeover Offers
abstract: Salesforce Said to be Preparing for Takeover Offers | Goldman Sachs Backs Bitcoin Company | Programmer’s Trial Resumes After 2 Jurors Removed | Secret Shutting Down
lead_paragraph: SALESFORCE SAID TO BE PREPARING FOR TAKEOVER OFFERS  | Who wants to buy Salesforce.com? That was the big question Wednesday following a report by Bloomberg News that the cloud software giant had hired financial advisers to field takeover inquiries after it was approached by a potential buyer. Unidentified people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News that it was not certain that any deal would be struck, and they didn’t name any possible buyers.

headline: In Code We Trust
abstract: Technology has upended our economy. Can technology save it?
lead_paragraph: When Caesar Augustus minted the denarius coin, around 4 A.D., he did so with a decree that it be made almost entirely of silver. But over the coming decades, as the financial health of the Roman Empire declined — largely because of its increasingly independent army, which demanded ever more money to subdue the rebellious provinces — the emperors began, slowly at first, mixing in copper to stretch the silver further. By 280 A.D., a denarius was 98 percent copper, with a thin silver wash on the surface. The implication was clear to every Roman: Here, in their hands, was a physical manifestation of the empire’s deepening desperation. Whatever proclamations the emperor might make, the coin told the truth.

headline: Goldman and IDG Put $50 Million to Work in a Bitcoin Company
abstract: Despite fading interest from the public, Wall Street has been quietly looking at the virtual currency, which can be sent securely, cheaply and almost instantly around the world.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is becoming the first major bank to make a significant investment in a Bitcoin-focused company, giving a vote of confidence to the embattled virtual currency.

headline: Want a Steady Income? There’s an App for That
abstract: A Silicon Valley start-up wants to put workers on an even keel.
lead_paragraph: Heather Jacobs, a chain-­spa masseuse in Simi Valley, Calif., never knows how much money is coming her way. When her spa charges $99 for a 55-­minute massage, she makes $18. But if she books just two massages in a six-­hour workday, the spa must raise her day’s pay to minimum wage, which is $9 an hour. Jacobs, who is 28, can’t be sure how many hours she will get or how many walk-­ins will choose her — a 5-foot-­2, 96-­pound masseuse who looks as if she could manage only a 1 on the four-­point pressure scale, though she is really a 3, verging on a 4. Her paychecks, which come every two weeks, have been as high as $700 and as low as $90. She also freelances for a gym, offering passers-­by free massages on the chance they might join; the gym doesn’t pay her, so for that she earns only tips. She seeks out private clients too, especially around the 27th of the month, when her credit-­card bill, with its $90 minimum payment, is due.

headline: Can Bitcoin Conquer Argentina?
abstract: With its volatile currency and dysfunctional banks, the country is the perfect place to experiment with a new digital currency.
lead_paragraph: Dante Castiglione stalked through the doors of a glass-walled office tower on the edge of downtown Buenos Aires, just a few hundred feet from the old port district. In the crowded elevator, he shook his head and muttered under his breath about the stresses of the day and his profession. “I swear, this job can kill me,” he said, his eyes cast downward.

headline: Reading The Times With Andy Borowitz
abstract: The political satirist Andy Borowitz reads The New York Times on April 16, 2015.
lead_paragraph: Andy Borowitz is the creator of the news satire column The Borowitz Report and a memoir, “An Unexpected Twist.”

headline: The Muddied Meaning of ‘Mindfulness’
abstract: If the word seems like a badge for the self-satisfied set, that’s because its true meaning has become obscured.
lead_paragraph: Most newly stylish coinages carry with them some evidence of grammatical trauma. Consider “affluencer,” “selfie,” “impactful.” Notes of cynicism and cutesiness come through. But every now and then a bright exception to this dispiriting routine appears. A rookie word makes its big-league debut, a stadium of pedants prepares to peg it with tomatoes and — nothing. A halfhearted heckle. The new word looks only passably pathetic. Maddeningly, it has heft.

headline: Today in Politics: Guns Give Republicans a Reprieve From Discord
abstract: Republican candidates and potential candidates will have plenty to agree with at the annual National Rifle Association leadership conference.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. Former Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island says he’s considering running for president, and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia sees Lee’s surrender to Grant as a model for national grace. President Obama continues his trip to Panama, by way of Jamaica and Bob Marley‘s house, and the friendship between Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Jeb Bush, the state’s former governor, may be tested in a Republican primary. In Tennessee, however, the Republican candidates and potential candidates will have plenty to agree with at the annual National Rifle Association leadership conference.

headline: SendGrid Account Breach Was Used to Attack Coinbase, a Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: Coinbase, one of the most popular Bitcoin exchanges, confirmed that hackers had compromised its SendGrid account, though it said no Bitcoin were stolen.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers targeted SendGrid, a mass email service used by 180,000 companies including Uber, Pinterest, Spotify and Foursquare, to infiltrate Coinbase, one of the most popular Bitcoin exchanges.

headline: In Accepting Bitcoin, Rand Paul Raises Money and Questions
abstract: Some say the virtual currency will one day be a part of all presidential campaigns. But its untraceable nature stirs concerns of illegal contributions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Presidential fund-raising, never known for its transparency, may have just become even more secretive.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama’s Trip to Panama Includes a Cuban Subplot
abstract: President Obama begins a trip to Panama where he may or may not have a much-watched meeting with President Raúl Castro of Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where a short-lived power failure briefly shut down the government. Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago gets to keep his job after a runoff, while Secretary of State John Kerry will meet with Jewish leaders to try and ease their concerns over a possible nuclear agreement with Iran. Representative Charles B. Rangel has recipe suggestions, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky hit the ground running after announcing his candidacy. President Obama begins a trip to Panama where he may or may not have a much-watched meeting with President Raúl Castro of Cuba.

headline: Wall Street and Silicon Valley Form an Uneasy Alliance
abstract: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists have done their best to resist or reduce Wall Street’s entreaties, but it appears that a new relationship has begun to develop.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has always had an uneasy relationship with Wall Street.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Strengthens Its Roots
abstract: Silicon Valley Bank has maintained a competitive edge among start-ups and venture capitalists by understanding the local culture — jeans and all.
lead_paragraph: While Wall Street banks scramble to stake claims in the booming technology industry, they are finding a smaller one already firmly entrenched.

headline: Investing Early On for Insights, Not Profits
abstract: BBVA, the global Spanish bank, has established a venture capital fund in Silicon Valley that is more interested in fruitful partnerships than profits.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The small office on the edge of the financial district here serves as a kind of listening post for a giant Spanish bank.

headline: Inquiry of Silk Road Website Spurred Agents’ Own Illegal Acts, Officials Say
abstract: The agents, one with the Drug Enforcement Administration and one with the Secret Service, have been charged with money laundering and wire fraud.
lead_paragraph: On the so-called dark web, drug dealing and other illicit sales have thrived in recent years, the authorities have said, through hidden websites like Silk Road and hard-to-trace digital currencies like Bitcoins.

headline: What’s New, Pussycat? Meerkat!
abstract: South by Southwest is obsessed with cats, from Grumpy Cat to Meerkat, but what if the masters of detachment could talk back to an Internet focused on attachment?
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — PITY the poor cat.

headline: Crowdfunded Entrepreneurs, Tripped Up by the Taxman
abstract: Campaigns on sites like Kickstarter can help a small business get started. But the complex income and sales tax reckoning can come as a surprise.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Wecker, a fledgling Salt Lake City entrepreneur, had a hit on her hands at the end of December: She collected $42,000 in pledges from the crowdfunding site Kickstarter for more than 300 orders of a stylish diaper bag she had designed.

headline: ‘The Age of Cryptocurrency,’ by Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey
abstract: A look at the rapidly evolving world of digital money.
lead_paragraph: Money, “The Age of Cryptocurrency” ­explains, is “a medium of exchange, a unit of account and a store of value.” But for Schopenhauer it was “human happiness in the abstract,” and for Dostoyevsky “coined liberty.” These passion metaphors reflect the febrile excitement about Bitcoin that Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey, both of The Wall Street Journal, share in their wide-ranging, interesting account of the origin, past and possible future of this virtual-money wannabe.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Banks Pass Fed Tests
abstract: All the large U.S. banks pass the Fed’s stress tests. | The Utah Legislature approves a white-collar felon registry. | Endo tops Valeant’s offer for Salix. | Alibaba plans to invest in Snapchat.
lead_paragraph: U.S. BANKS PASS FED EXAM | The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that all the large United States banks passed its so-called stress tests, which aim to assess whether they can weather a financial storm, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Bank of America passed only provisionally and could still fail later this year if it does not fix deficiencies that the Fed identified. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley each had to alter their planned payouts to investors to achieve passing grades. The American units of Deutsche Bank, the German banking giant, and Santander of Spain failed the tests outright.

headline: Former JPMorgan Executive Blythe Masters Joins Bitcoin-Related Start-Up
abstract: Ms. Masters, who once headed JPMorgan Chase’s commodities unit, is joining Digital Asset Holdings, a firm seeking to streamline financial transactions.
lead_paragraph: A prominent former executive at JPMorgan Chase has left the world of commodity trading for the virtual world of digital transactions.

headline: Morning Agenda: Citigroup’s Resurgence
abstract: Citigroup’s traders and investment bankers have come roaring back since the financial crisis. | Credit Suisse gets a risk expert in new chief. | Emerging markets are losing their luster. | Former JPMorgan executive joins a Bitcoin start-up.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP’S RESURGENCE | Seven years after Citigroup teetered on the brink, the bank’s traders and investment bankers have come roaring back, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The bank’s resurgence on Wall Street, which has involved acquiring huge amounts of derivatives, comes as many of its rivals pull back in the face of new regulations intended to make the financial system safer. But even as the bank has surged ahead, it has not trumpeted its comeback. Instead, its most senior executives have largely emphasized streamlining operations that have little to do with Wall Street, like agreeing to sell a unit that focuses on subprime loans.

headline: Morning Agenda: Big Banks Pass Stress Tests
abstract: The nation’s biggest banks pass the Fed’s latest stress tests. | AbbVie goes on the defensive after deal for cancer drug maker. | Bidders show interest in the government’s third Bitcoin auction. | Nasdaq’s long climb back to 5,000.
lead_paragraph: BIG BANKS PASS STRESS TESTS | All 31 of the nation’s biggest banks appear to have enough financial strength to survive a severe downturn in the United States economy, according to the results of the so-called stress tests that the Federal Reserve released on Thursday. But some banks fared better than others, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes.

headline: U.S. Auction Suggests Lingering Interest in Bitcoin
abstract: The United States Marshals Service said that 14 bidders took part in an auction on Thursday for 50,000 Bitcoins, worth around $14 million.
lead_paragraph: The falling price of Bitcoin has not entirely quashed investor enthusiasm for the virtual currency.

headline: Morning Agenda: Buffett Hints at Successor
abstract: Warren E. Buffett hinted at a successor in his annual letter to shareholders. | Wells Fargo puts a cap on subprime auto loans. | Semiconductor giants agree to merger. | A former Tyco chief’s path to obscurity. | Bitcoin’s true value may lie in its underlying technology.
lead_paragraph: BUFFETT HINTS AT SUCCESSOR | Warren E. Buffett released his annual letter to shareholders on Saturday, reflecting on his 50 years in control of Berkshire Hathaway, one of the world’s biggest companies. In his 24,000-word letter to commemorate his golden anniversary at the company, Mr. Buffett looked back on less prescient moves. He also railed against investment bankers, accusing them of being nearsighted and self-serving.

headline: Data Security Is Becoming the Sparkle in Bitcoin
abstract: With the price of Bitcoin plummeting, the technology that stores the currency’s transactions is gaining value as a safe and open way to keep other kinds of records.
lead_paragraph: Some couples opt for a traditional wedding, while others go for the Elvis impersonator in Las Vegas. But David Mondrus and Joyce Bayo may be the first to have incorporated Bitcoin.

headline: Morning Agenda: Britain to Examine Competition in Banking
abstract: A British regulator is planning to review competition in investment banking. | Greece requests an extension to its loan agreement. | Two deals put the spotlight on a secretive banking family. | Uber expands its financing round.
lead_paragraph: BRITAIN TO EXAMINE COMPETITION IN BANKING | The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said on Thursday that it planned to review whether competition was working properly in the corporate and investment banking sectors, DealBook’s Chad Bray reports. The regulator conducted a similar review of so-called wholesale securities and investment markets last year, and plans to consider looking at the asset management sector this year.

headline: Digital Currency
abstract: You’ll flip for this puzzle by Jason Flinn.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If you’re looking for the Dramamine, it’s right here. Today’s puzzle by Jason Flinn had a few wild loop-de-LOOPS in it but, if you’re reading this, everyone’s stomachs should be settling down by now.

headline: U.S. Announces Third Bitcoin Auction
abstract: The U.S. Marshals Service will auction 50,000 Bitcoins seized in connection with the online marketplace Silk Road.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshals Service announced on Wednesday that it would auction 50,000 Bitcoins, worth nearly $12 million, seized in connection with the online marketplace Silk Road.

headline: Morning Agenda: Standoff Over Greek Debt
abstract: All sides in the negotiations on Greek debt are betting others will blink first. | Lyft is is talks to raise about $250 million. | Expedia agrees to buy Orbitz. | Law schools are adding business-related offerings.
lead_paragraph: | David Carr, a champion of media and a friend and mentor to so many, died last night. This newsletter is dedicated to him.

headline: Larry Summers Likes the Idea of Bitcoin
abstract: The former Treasury secretary said the virtual currency could help reduce costs and inefficiencies in the global payments system. But so could other payment technologies.
lead_paragraph: As Treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers took on complex economic policy.

headline: Hong Kong bitcoin scandal leaves investors in the dark
abstract: Bitcoin investors in Hong Kong may have lost millions of U.S. dollars after an operator there shuttered, thought to be a ponzi scheme front. Pamela Ambler reports.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin investors in Hong Kong may have lost millions of U.S. dollars after an operator there shuttered, thought to be a ponzi scheme front. Pamela Ambler reports.

headline: New York Today:  Abandoned and Vanishing Places
abstract: Wednesday: Racing to photograph derelict buildings, fair weather, and a grand jury indicts the police officer who shot Akai Gurley.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning.

headline: Man Behind Silk Road Website Is Convicted on All Counts
abstract: The most serious counts carry potential life sentences for Ross W. Ulbricht, who prosecutors said operated the online black market that sold drugs and other illicit goods.
lead_paragraph: A California man behind the website Silk Road, once a thriving online black market for the sale of heroin, cocaine, LSD and other drugs and illicit goods, was convicted on Wednesday of all seven counts related to the enterprise.

headline: In Closing Arguments, Conflicting Accounts of Man’s Role in Silk Road
abstract: Jurors are expected to begin deliberations on Wednesday in the trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, who is accused of operating the online black market.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor asked a Manhattan jury on Tuesday to convict a California man, Ross W. Ulbricht, of narcotics trafficking conspiracy and other charges in a trial involving Silk Road, the black-market website for drugs and other illicit goods.

headline: New Magazine Teaches Children Financial Lessons
abstract: The financial editor of NBC’s “Today” show and Time for Kids, a division of Time Inc., have introduced a magazine intended to teach financial literacy to fourth, fifth and sixth graders.
lead_paragraph: Jean Chatzky, the financial editor of NBC’s “Today” show, has made a career sharing personal finance tips with adults. Now, she is trying to reach a much younger audience.

headline: $3 Tip on a $4 Cup of Coffee? Gratuities Grow, Automatically
abstract: Increasing varieties of digital payment options are expanding when and how much people are encouraged to tip.
lead_paragraph: The flat white coffee drink was $4. A suggested tip was $3.

headline: Europe’s Young Entrepreneurs
abstract: At a conference in Madrid on European youth in business, 200 or so teenage achievers discussed what it takes to break potential hurdles to the young and business-minded on the Continent.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — When Jordan Casey took to the stage to present his technology business, he jumped onto the platform rather than walking up the access ramp.

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo as Takeover Target
abstract: Spinning off its stake in Alibaba may make Yahoo a takeover target. |Deutsche Bank swings to profit. | McDonald’s replaces its chief executive. | A push for a greater government role in housing finance.
lead_paragraph: After Yahoo completes the spinoff of its $39 billion stake in the Alibaba Group, the Silicon Valley stalwart may not have much time to turn its core Internet businesses around, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. When the spinoff is done, investors and analysts say, Yahoo could become a takeover target.

headline: At Silk Road Trial, Lawyers Fight to Include Evidence They Call Vital: Emoji
abstract: How chats and other messages and their symbols should be presented in court has become a subplot in the trial of a California man charged with running the online black market.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, a California man charged with running an online black-market bazaar called Silk Road, had barely begun when an unusual objection was lodged.

headline: Coinbase, a Bitcoin Exchange, Is Operating Without Licenses So Far
abstract: Coinbase said this week that it had opened as the first regulated Bitcoin exchange in several states, but it does not have licenses in New York or California.
lead_paragraph: The best-funded company in the Bitcoin industry appears to be operating without the proper licenses in the world’s financial capital.

headline: Morning Agenda: Winklevosses Plan Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: The Winklevoss twins are planning to open a Bitcoin exchange. | Hutchison Whampoa is in talks to buy O2 of Britain. | Attractive pay packages for chiefs of JPMorgan and Goldman. | Markets respond to E.C.B. stimulus plan.
lead_paragraph: WINKLEVOSSES PLAN BITCOIN EXCHANGE | The Winklevoss twins, two of the biggest boosters of Bitcoin, are trying to firm up support for the virtual currency by creating the first regulated Bitcoin exchange for American customers, Nathaniel Popper and Sydney Ember write in DealBook. The brothers have hired engineers from top hedge funds, enlisted a bank and engaged regulators with the aim of opening their exchange, which they have financed themselves, in the coming months. They are calling the exchange Gemini ‒ Latin for twins.

headline: Winklevoss Twins Aim to Take Bitcoin Mainstream
abstract: The brothers have hired engineers from top hedge funds, enlisted a bank and engaged regulators with the aim of opening their exchange in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin, the virtual currency that was once the talk of the financial world, has been taking a beating over the last year with the price tumbling downward.

headline: In Journal, Man Wrote of Creating Silk Road, an Online Black Market, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Reading from what they say is his diary, prosecutors in Federal District Court highlighted Ross W. Ulbricht’s ideas for starting and expanding the online black market.
lead_paragraph: Long before the website Silk Road became an online black market for drugs and other illicit goods, it began its life of underground commerce with the sale of homegrown hallucinogenic mushrooms, prosecutors have said.

headline: Unlocking Prisons and Reopening Wounds
abstract: While Peter Carey’s “Amnesia” may be about a hacker, the novel has much less to do with computers than with Australian-American tensions during the 1942 Battle of Brisbane.
lead_paragraph: Peter Carey’s “Amnesia” has been received by some as an excitingly timely novel: “the story of WikiLeaks as if transmogrified by Dickens and turned into a thrilling fable for our post-Edward Snowden era,” as a writer in The Guardian has put it. But anyone expecting that kind of urgency can plow a long way into “Amnesia,” wondering when the fireworks start.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Predicament
abstract: Shareholders are facing a quandary in the battle for Family Dollar. | President Obama sets agenda to help the middle class. | S.&P. is nearing costly settlements with the U.S. | Profit at Morgan Stanley disappoints.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders are facing a predicament in the battle for Family Dollar, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. On Thursday, Family Dollar shareholders will vote on a proposed $8.5 billion acquisition by Dollar Tree, which is offering about $76 a share. If they vote yes, “it will be the death knell for a competing bid by Dollar General that is about $4 a share higher,” Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.

headline: Coinbase, a Bitcoin Start-Up, Raises $75 Million in Vote of Confidence
abstract: Investors in Coinbase include the New York Stock Exchange, the Spanish bank BBVA and Vikram S. Pandit.
lead_paragraph: Coinbase, one of the most popular Bitcoin wallet providers, announced on Tuesday that it had closed a $75 million financing round, the biggest yet for a virtual currency start-up.

headline: Bitcoin Is a Victim of Disinflation
abstract: In a more ebullient and inflationary world, the novelty and limited supply of Bitcoins might appeal, Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is proving a big disappointment. The virtual currency is down 33 percent against the dollar in 2015, and 71 percent in the last year. There is almost certainly more bad news to come.

headline: Focus Is on Bitcoin Trader at Trial Over Silk Road Black Market
abstract: A federal agent said he became convinced that the person behind the Silk Road black-market website was Mark Karpeles, operator of the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of operating the online black-market bazaar Silk Road was not the person government investigators had focused on early in their hunt, new court testimony shows.

headline: Morning Agenda: Profit Falls at JPMorgan
abstract: JPMorgan reports an unexpected drop in fourth-quarter profit. | MetLife sues to fight its designation as “systemically important.” | The Bitcoin industry is wrestling with a price slump.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase kicked off fourth-quarter earnings season, reporting an unexpected drop in profit, DealBook’s Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank said its earnings fell 7 percent, to $4.9 billion, or $1.19 a share, from the $5.6 billion, or $1.30 a share, in the period a year earlier. The most recent results fell short of the $1.31 a share expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters.

headline: As Bitcoin’s Price Slides, Signs of a Squeeze
abstract: Some miners of the virtual currency are starting to feel the effects of a sustained decline in prices.
lead_paragraph: The price of Bitcoin slid further on Tuesday, dipping to its lowest level since the spring of 2013.  The downward spiral, which began early last year, suggests that confidence in the virtual currency may be dwindling.

headline: Trial Over a Man’s Role in a Black Market Begins
abstract: Ross W. Ulbricht has pleaded not guilty to charges that include narcotics trafficking, computer hacking and money laundering conspiracies.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht, safe to say, will be like few that have ever taken place in Federal District Court.

headline: Morning Agenda: Shire’s Deal for NPS
abstract: Shire agrees to buy NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion. | Banks brace for a jolt as the price of oil falls. | Kicking Dodd-Frank in the teeth. | David A. O’Neil, a federal prosecutor, is joining the law firm Debevoise & Plimpton.
lead_paragraph: The Irish drug maker Shire has agreed to acquire NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion, the first big corporate acquisition of the year, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. Shire, based in Dublin, said on Sunday that it would pay $46 a share for NPS, which is based in New Jersey and specializes in drugs for gastrointestinal disorders. That represents a 51 percent increase over NPS’s share price on Dec. 16, before rumors of the deal first surfaced. Shire will pay for NPS using all cash.

headline: Bitcoin Exchange Bitstamp Resumes Services
abstract: Bitstamp said it had adopted new security measures and protocols to prevent future breaches. The company had suspended its services after some virtual wallets were compromised.
lead_paragraph: Bitstamp, the prominent Bitcoin exchange that suspended its services this week after a security breach, has resumed operations, capping a period of uncertainty in the virtual currency industry.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bond Prices Flash Warning
abstract: The bond market may be sounding an economic warning. | Why McDonald’s isn’t Shake Shack and shouldn’t be. | Coach adds celebrity cachet with acquisition of Stuart Weitzman. | Bitcoin exchange Bitstamp suspends services after breach.
lead_paragraph: Despite signs that the United States economy is accelerating, a huge bond market with a strong track record for predicting economic problems may be sounding a warning, DealBook’s Peter Eavis reports. As they do in times of stress, investors are seeking the safety of government bonds. In turn, the prices of government bonds are rallying, pushing their yields to lows. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, for instance, fell to 1.94 percent on Tuesday. In Europe, yields are even lower.

headline: Jitters After Bitcoin Exchange Suspends Services
abstract: Bitstamp, a popular Bitcoin exchange, said on Tuesday that some of its virtual wallets were compromised on Sunday and that it had lost roughly 19,000 Bitcoins, worth about $5 million.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest Bitcoin exchanges suspended services on Tuesday, prompting unease in a virtual currency industry already scarred by the collapse last year of Mt. Gox, once its most prominent exchange.

headline: Morning Agenda: Data Leak at Morgan Stanley
abstract: Breach puts Morgan Stanley client data up for sale. | Steven A. Cohen’s family office posts a big gain in 2014. | Stock markets shudder on oil fears. | An academic paper is at the heart of a dispute about corporate governance.
lead_paragraph: After account records for clients of Morgan Stanley were put up for sale last month on the information-sharing site Pastebin, the bank traced the breach to a financial adviser working out of its New York offices, a 30-year-old named Galen Marsh, Nathaniel Popper writes in DealBook, citing a person involved in the investigation. Mr. Marsh, who had been with Morgan Stanley since 2008, was quickly fired and is currently the subject of a criminal investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a person briefed on the investigation said. The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority is also examining the matter.

headline: Morgan Stanley Breach Put Client Data Up for Sale on Pastebin, an Online Site
abstract: Morgan Stanley traced the leak to Galen Marsh, a young financial adviser, but said he did not share the data or use it for financial gain.
lead_paragraph: In mid-December, a posting appeared on the Internet site Pastebin offering six million account records, including passwords and login data for clients of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banner Year for Fund-Raising
abstract: Last year was a good one for the business of raising money. | Euro falls lower as central bank hints at stimulus. | A stress test for Mario Draghi. | Bitcoin Foundation parts ways with global policy counsel.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, last year was a good one for the business of raising money, in either the public or the private markets, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. Some 1,205 issuers raised nearly $249 billion globally, according to data from Thomson Reuters, making 2014 one of the busiest since 2010 for companies seeking to list on the stock markets. Such enthusiasm has prompted comparisons to the dot-com boom and bust of 1999-2000.

headline: How My Mom Got Hacked
abstract: Navigating the nefarious, shadowy world of ransomware criminals.
lead_paragraph: MY mother received the ransomnote on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving. It popped up on her computer screen soon after she’d discovered that all of her files had been locked. “Your files are encrypted,” it announced. “To get the key to decrypt files you have to pay 500 USD.” If my mother failed to pay within a week, the price would go up to $1,000. After that, her decryption key would be destroyed and any chance of accessing the 5,726 files on her PC — all of her data — would be lost forever.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation Parts Ways With Its Global Policy Counsel
abstract: The dismissal of Jim Harper comes as the Bitcoin Foundation is shifting its focus, from policy advocacy to Bitcoin technology and infrastructure development.
lead_paragraph: Jim Harper, whose appointment as the Bitcoin Foundation’s global policy counsel last March was viewed as a sign that the advocacy group was taking digital currency regulation seriously, has been dismissed from the foundation.

headline: 1. ___________ Weighs In on Goldman’s Crossword Puzzle
abstract: Hint: The New York Times’s master of all words across and down.
lead_paragraph: The crossword puzzles that appear daily in The New York Times have legions of fans.

headline: Morning Agenda: Goldman Promotes Star Deal Maker
abstract: Goldman names John E. Waldron co-head of its investment bank. | Regulators deem MetLife “too big to fail.” | Another big whistle-blower reward in Bank of America case. | London tenants win battle over U.S. equity firm.
lead_paragraph: GOLDMAN PROMOTES STAR DEAL MAKER | Goldman Sachs has promoted John E. Waldron, one of the bank’s star deal makers, to become a co-head of its investment bank, succeeding John S. Weinberg, a scion of one of the firm’s most famous families, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. The move will put Mr. Waldron in charge, along with Richard Gnodde and David Solomon, of running the firm’s prominent corporate advisory practice. The announcement on Thursday is the latest change in the leadership of Goldman’s powerful investment bank.

headline: New York Regulator Outlines Changes to Bitcoin Rules
abstract: In a speech on Thursday, Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, provided the most detail yet on revisions to his proposed Bitcoin rules.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s proposed Bitcoin regulations are coming into sharper focus.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Test for Post-Crisis Banking System
abstract: Market turmoil will test Washington’s efforts to bolster the financial system. | Bond investors skittish over emerging markets. | Venture capital’s feeding frenzy. | Email newsletter theSkimm raises $6.25 million in financing.
lead_paragraph: The market turmoil this week will test Washington’s efforts over the last five years to bolster the financial system, Peter Eavis reports in DealBook. Investors are stampeding out of risky markets, dumping junk bonds issued by American energy companies that have borrowed heavily to exploit the shale oil boom. A steep slide in the price of oil could now cause some of the companies to default, analysts say. But the most dangerous pain is occurring abroad, particularly in Russia, which is dealing with a currency crisis.

headline: Time Inc. Begins Accepting Bitcoin Payments
abstract: The magazine publisher Time Inc. is teaming up with Coinbase and will accept Bitcoin payments for subscriptions of Fortune, Health, This Old House and Travel + Leisure.
lead_paragraph: A large magazine publisher is trying to stay on the digital cutting edge.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Future of Payments
abstract: Oil falls below $60 a barrel. Microsoft now accepts Bitcoin. And an Indianapolis gun-store owner offers tips for “gun gifting” this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: American Express Chief Ken Chenault Sees Potential in Bitcoin’s Technology
abstract: Alternative currencies, Mr. Chenault says, are like Napster and iTunes, having the potential to drive industry change.
lead_paragraph: Many Bitcoin supporters hope that the virtual currency will one day transform the payments system by enabling the nearly instantaneous transfer of value across the globe.

headline: Ex-JPMorgan Executive to Join Circle, a Digital Currency Start-Up
abstract: Paul Camp, who led JPMorgan’s global transaction services business before leaving the bank in July, is joining Circle Internet Financial, a start-up that processes digital transactions.
lead_paragraph: A former JPMorgan Chase executive is set to join a digital currency start-up, part of a fledgling industry that is seeking to topple the traditional financial system.

headline: Morning Agenda: New Capital Rule for Big Banks
abstract: The Fed proposes a rule to increase big banks’ capital requirements. | Wall Street seeks to reshape Dodd-Frank. | A near sweep in the government’s latest Bitcoin auction. | The co-founder of TheStreet is hit with his own insult.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is nudging big banks to shrink, Peter Eavis reports in DealBook. On Tuesday, the Fed proposed a rule that would increase capital requirements for the nation’s eight biggest banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs. By increasing the requirements, the Fed is looking to make large banks more resilient to financial shocks. A bank with higher capital depends less on borrowed money, which may not be available in times of stress. Increasing capital may also reduce the chances that a big bank’s problems will weigh on the wider economy. Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, said on Tuesday that the proposed rule might persuade banks to shrink.

headline: At an Auction of Bitcoins Seized From Silk Road, SecondMarket Wins Big
abstract: The SecondMarket exchange won all but one of the 20 Bitcoin blocks in the government’s auction. The venture capitalist Timothy C. Draper, who swept the first auction, won only 2,000 Bitcoins this time.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin frenzy appears to be fading. But an upstart exchange made a big bet last week that the virtual currency still held promise as an investment.

headline: Morning Agenda: Merck Goes After Cubist
abstract: Merck agrees to buy Cubist in a deal valued at $9.5 billion. | A hedge fund keeps an S.E.C. inquiry quiet. | Big deals are back this year. | Deal makers regain their power on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The big drug maker Merck & Company announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy Cubist Pharmaceuticals for $9.5 billion, including debt, Merck said in a statement. Under the terms of the agreement, Merck will acquire Cubist for $102 a share in cash, or 35 percent above Cubist’s average stock price over the last five trading days, Merck said.

headline: Venture Capitalist Tim Draper Wins Small Piece of Bitcoin Auction
abstract: After successfully bidding for all the Bitcoins in the government’s first auction in June, the venture capitalist says he won just one block of 2,000 Bitcoins in Thursday’s sale.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Marshals Service opened its second Bitcoin auction on Thursday, some bidders were not optimistic about their chances. After all, a single bidder had won all of the nearly 30,000 Bitcoins in the government’s first auction in June, leaving the rest of the participants discouraged.

headline: Morning Agenda: Uber Garners $40 Billion Valuation
abstract: Uber closes a $1.2 billion round of financing. | The owners of the 76ers are taking a page out of the private equity playbook. | Only 11 bidders took part in the second Bitcoin auction. | Microsoft and Barnes & Noble end their Nook partnership.
lead_paragraph: UBER GARNERS $40 BILLION VALUATION | Uber is amassing a war chest to be the world’s private driving service, Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. On Thursday, the start-up closed a new $1.2 billion round of financing, with investors valuing the company at a staggering $40 billion. This comes on top of the $1.5 billion that Uber had already raised. And Uber may not be done yet. The company may eventually sell an additional $600 million in stock, and it is working with Goldman Sachs to sell, potentially, another $1 billion in debt to some of the Wall Street firm’s wealthy private clients.

headline: Second Bitcoin Auction Draws Fewer Bidders
abstract: The Marshals Service said that 11 registered bidders had taken part and that the agency had received 27 bids, far fewer than the 45 bidders and 63 bids in the first auction in June.
lead_paragraph: Investor enthusiasm for Bitcoin may be waning.

headline: Who Should Own the Internet?
abstract: The destruction of privacy widens the existing power imbalance between the ruling factions and everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Turning Point: The top E.U. court orders Google to grant the “right to be forgotten.'’

headline: Morning Agenda: Young Bankers Flock to Private Equity
abstract: Young Wall Street bankers are enamored with private equity. | An activist investor takes aim at TheStreet. | Brazilians are turning to pawnshops for cash.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG BANKERS FLOCK TO PRIVATE EQUITY | Wall Street’s young bankers are enamored with private equity, William Alden reports in DealBook. Nearly 36 percent of junior investment bankers who started two-year jobs in 2012 have now joined private equity firms, according to research by Vettery, a start-up recruiting firm. That level exceeded the 27.5 percent of junior bankers who stayed in the same group at their bank, Vettery said. The data, which covers about 1,400 analysts, sheds more light on a recruiting race that begins for so-called analysts soon after they start work at investment banks.

headline: Computing Goes to the Cloud. So Does Crime.
abstract: While public clouds, by their nature, provide opportunities for malicious hackers, the sophistication of the systems and their management allow for new ways to defend against attacks.
lead_paragraph: As more of our world, from family photos to financial information, moves into the cloud, malicious hackers are following.

headline: Morning Agenda: Using Pay to Encourage Public Service
abstract: Encouraging public service, through the revolving door. | Web thieves are taking aim at the pharmaceutical industry. | Law schools battle for top students. | Lending club sets price range for I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: USING PAY TO ENCOURAGE PUBLIC SERVICE | A recent letter sent to the boards of Wall Street’s biggest banks has created quite a stir within the halls of banks and parts of corporate America, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column. The letter, sent by Heather Slavkin Corzo, director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s office of investment, asked why banks routinely pay out special compensation packages to executives who leave to take government jobs when those packages were intended to retain them. But perhaps the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has it backward, Mr. Sorkin writes.

headline: Morning Agenda: Financing for Suit by Steven Cohen’s Ex-Wife
abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s ex-wife gets outside financing for her lawsuit. | ‘Poison puts’ develop a downside. | Trustee moves to repay Mt. Gox creditors. | Philip A. Falcone to Depart the Harbinger Group.
lead_paragraph: FINANCING FOR SUIT BY STEVEN COHEN’S EX-WIFE | Steven A. Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein reports. Patricia Cohen continues to pursue Mr. Cohen, claiming that the billionaire investor cheated her out of money during their divorce some two decades ago and potentially owes her millions of dollars. Helping to fuel the long-running legal battle is Asta Funding, a financial backer of a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that has provided litigation financing to Ms. Cohen. Asta and the firm that is financing Ms. Cohen’s lawsuit, Balance Point Divorce Funding, have an agreement to share in the proceeds of legal recoveries by clients. Ms. Cohen’s lawyers are scheduled to take a deposition from Mr. Cohen on Dec. 10.

headline: Trustee Moves to Repay Creditors in Mt. Gox Bitcoin Exchange
abstract: Kraken, a California-based Bitcoin exchange, will work with the trustee to return about 200,000 Bitcoin to Mt. Gox’s 127,000 creditors.
lead_paragraph: Customers of Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, are closer to getting back at least some of the money they lost this year when it shut down and announced that their funds had gone missing.

headline: Morning Agenda: Return of the Mega-Merger
abstract: Wall Street is on pace for a big year of deal-making. | William A. Ackman may have lost Allergan, but he still came away a winner. | The Justice Department is weighing a civil suit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial. | U.S. plans second Bitcoin auction.
lead_paragraph: RETURN OF THE MEGA-MERGER | Mega-mergers are back. Mergers worth $100 billion, made on Monday, put Wall Street on pace for a year of deal-making rivaling those during the dot-com bubble and the private equity upsurge just before the financial crisis, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The announcement of two mega-deals ‒ Actavis’s $66 billion acquisition of the Botox maker Allergan and Halliburton’s $34.6 billion takeover of the oil field services firm Baker Hughes ‒ made Monday a symbolic tipping point, Mr. Gelles writes. With those transactions, about $1.5 trillion in deals targeting United States companies have been announced this year, the most since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline: Another Bitcoin Auction to Be Held by U.S. Marshals
abstract: The latest auction is for $19 million in Bitcoins found on computer hardware belonging to Ross Ulbricht, who is accused of creating the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshals Service announced on Monday that it would auction 50,000 Bitcoins, worth around $19 million, seized in connection with the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.

headline: Islamic State Says It Plans to Issue Its Own Currency
abstract: The leaders of the Islamic State have created their own currency, part of a grandiose plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.
lead_paragraph: They have paraded their own flag, formed courts and ministries and issued license plates. Now, the leaders of the Islamic State, the violent jihadist group that has seized parts of Syria and Iraq, have created their own currency, part of a plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.

headline: Welcome to the Failure Age!
abstract: In this economy, losers will be the biggest winners.
lead_paragraph: When you pull off Highway 101 and head into Sunnyvale, Calif., the first thing you notice is how boring innovation looks up close. This small Silicon Valley city, which abuts both Cupertino, the home of Apple, and Mountain View, the site of the Googleplex, is where Lockheed built the Poseidon nuclear missile. It’s where the forebear of NASA did some of its most important research and where a prototype for Pong debuted at a neighborhood bar. Countless ambitious start-ups — with names like Qvivr, Schoolfy, eCloset.me and PeerPal — appear in Sunnyvale every year. Aesthetically, though, the city is one enormous glass-and-stucco office park after another. Its dominant architectural feature, the five-story headquarters of Yahoo, a few minutes from Innovation Way, looks about as futuristic as a suburban hospital.

headline: Today in Small Business: Start-Ups Founded by Women
abstract: Seven-day postal service. Republicans don’t always hate business regulations. Is maple syrup good for anything besides pancakes and French toast?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: International Raids Target Sites Selling Contraband on the ‘Dark Web’
abstract: A joint European and American operation targeted sites that typically operated on the Tor network, which conceals the I.P. addresses of computers.
lead_paragraph: In the digital marketplace, they operated as a secret underground with names like Blue Sky and Silk Road 2.0 where anonymous buyers could purchase drugs, stolen credit cards and weapons, or even hire a hit man.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America’s Legal Hit
abstract: Bank of America takes a $400 million legal charge. | Details emerge on low-down-payment mortgage plan. | More twists in battle for Allergan.
lead_paragraph: BANK OF AMERICA RAISES LEGAL COSTS | Bank of America said in a news release on Thursday that it was nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the bank’s suspected manipulation of the currency market, saying it had increased its legal costs to deal with the inquiry, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The increased legal bill resulted in a $400 million charge that cut into the earnings that Bank of America reported for the third quarter a few weeks ago. The charge resulted in the bank’s reporting a loss of $232 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter.

lead_paragraph: Good morning on this pleasant Friday. Cars are driving slower, or at least are supposed to.

headline: Man Charged With Operating Silk Road 2.0, a Black Market Website
abstract: A criminal complaint said the website was created to replace the original Silk Road, used for drug sales and other illegal activities, which had been seized by the government.
lead_paragraph: A California man has been arrested and charged with operating an online marketplace created to be a successor to the original Silk Road website, a black market for drug sales and other illegal activity that used Bitcoins.

headline: Teenagers Stand Up to Backpage

lead_paragraph: IF prostitution of children is illegal, why is it that we allow an estimated 100,000 underage girls and boys to be sold for sex in America each year — many on a single American website, Backpage.com?

headline: Morning Agenda: Citigroup’s About-Face
abstract: Citigroup says it has to cut its third-quarter profit by $600 million because of legal expenses. | Apple chief’s coming out. | Judge approves bankruptcy plan for Stockton, Calif.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP CUTS THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT | Citigroup can’t seem to catch a break. On Thursday, the bank startled investors with an announcement that it had to lower its third-quarter profit by $600 million because of “rapidly evolving regulatory inquiries and investigations,” DealBook’s Michael Corkery, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write. Citigroup reported its results for the quarter two weeks ago, just before the legal development arose. Although the bank did not specify the development, people briefed on the matter attributed the nearly 18 percent drop in earnings to an investigation into whether Citigroup manipulated the price of foreign currencies. Since reporting its third-quarter results, the bank has edged nearer a settlement with at least one regulator in the case, the people said.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation’s Executive Director, Jon Matonis, Resigns
abstract: The Bitcoin Foundation said that Jon Matonis, who was named executive director in July 2013, will be succeeded by Patrick Murck, the foundation’s general counsel.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin Foundation announced on Thursday that Jon Matonis, one of the foundation’s founding board members, was stepping down as its executive director, effective on Friday. Mr. Matonis will remain on the foundation’s board until Dec. 31.

headline: UK charity cashes in on Bitcoin trend
abstract: It's been used to anonymously buy naked pictures of celebrities but it seems bitcoin also has a more charitable use.  As Ciara Lee reports the UK's RNLI, a lifeboat charity, is now accepting cyber currency donations.
lead_paragraph: It's been used to anonymously buy naked pictures of celebrities but it seems bitcoin also has a more charitable use.  As Ciara Lee reports the UK's RNLI, a lifeboat charity, is now accepting cyber currency donations.

headline: Morning Agenda: Shake-Up at Deutsche Bank
abstract: Deutsche Bank reports third-quarter earnings and management shake-up. | Facebook plans to increase spending. | The Fed is expected to end its bond-buying program. | A lesson on saying “no” to a hostile bid.
lead_paragraph: A day after announcing a management shuffle, Deutsche Bank reported on Wednesday that it had a net loss of about $117 million in the third quarter as it set aside more money to cover costs stemming from accusations of wrongdoing by its employees, Jack Ewing reports in DealBook. Profit in the quarter had been expected to suffer after Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, said last week that it had set aside an additional 894 million euros, or about $1.1 billion, to cover legal costs. The loss provides another reminder that Deutsche Bank and other large investment banks are still preoccupied with dealing with the excesses associated with the financial crisis, as well as increasing demands from regulators intent on curbing risk-taking by banks.

headline: Former S.E.C. Chairman to Advise Two Prominent Bitcoin Companies
abstract: Arthur Levitt Jr., who will serve as an adviser to BitPay, the Bitcoin payment processor, and Vaurum, an exchange for institutional investors, said he was intrigued by the challenge of defining virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Since it was introduced more than five years ago, Bitcoin has been viewed as a way to operate outside the realm of the existing financial system and the laws that govern it. But more recently, Bitcoin companies have been luring the financial establishment into their ranks.

headline: A Look Behind the Snapchat Photo Leak Claims
abstract: Three men who built a tool called Snapaved to store images from the messaging service have come forward to offer details of how a recent theft of thousands of private photos occurred.
lead_paragraph: Snapchat, a fast-growing Internet messaging service, promises its users that the things they share with each other will disappear within 10 seconds. But three men claim they wanted to prove that wasn’t quite true, “just for the fun of it.”

headline: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Swings to a Profit
abstract: JPMorgan Chase posts a third-quarter profit. | Warren E. Buffett promotes the Berkshire Hathaway brand. | Calculating the cost of Ebola | Derivatives change only goes so far.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase swung to a profit in the third quarter, but the announcement on Tuesday morning was marred by an early release of the results on a third-party website, DealBook’s Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank earned $5.57 billion in the quarter, or $1.36 a share, compared with a loss of $380 million in the quarter a year earlier, when the bank booked $7.2 billion in legal costs. Net revenue rose 5 percent, to $25.2 billion, from the third quarter of 2013. The earnings fell short of analysts’ estimates of $1.38 a share, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Earnings were reduced by $1.1 billion in legal expenses, or 26 cents a share, after taxes.

headline: Senate Adviser Jumps to Bitcoin Start-Up Coinbase
abstract: Coinbase, a popular digital wallet provider, has hired John Collins, a former adviser to the Senate Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee, as its head of government affairs.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin start-up Coinbase is bolstering its team as it seeks to deepen its engagement with regulators.

headline: A Teacher Accused of Abuse Seen to Have Never Grown Up
abstract: Sean Shaynak, a Brooklyn Technical High School teacher who faces 36 charges including sexual abuse and forcible touching, appeared forever stuck in high school to those who knew him.
lead_paragraph: For Sean Shaynak, the talented teenager whose high school classmates thought he could have been anything, nothing ever really stuck.

headline: Morning Agenda: Changing a Rule on Derivatives
abstract: A derivatives rule is set to change. | JPMorgan’s data breach causes alarm. | Chinese companies are scooping up real estate across the globe. | Former Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner defends the bailout of A.I.G.
lead_paragraph: DERIVATIVES RULE SET TO CHANGE | Regulators and large banks are expected to agree this weekend on a change to derivatives that is intended to curb the damage caused by the crash of a large bank, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Many in the industry view the change as evidence that banks and regulators are substantially reducing the threat that large banks pose to the financial system and the wider economy. But while consumer advocates say that they support the change, they also contend that it does not do enough to dislodge the privileged, and potentially precarious, position that they say derivatives still occupy in the financial system.

headline: Morning Agenda: More Trouble for Big Banks
abstract: Big banks face another round of U.S. charges. | Henry M. Paulson Jr. testifies that ‘punitive’ A.I.G. terms were necessary. | Investors cheer the breakup of HP. | Lawyers for Goldman and Libya’s sovereign fund clash in court.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing a fresh round of attacks on the world’s biggest banks, again questioning Wall Street’s role in a broad array of financial markets, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write. With evidence mounting that a number of foreign and American banks colluded to set the price of foreign currencies, prosecutors are aiming to file charges against at least one bank by the end of the year, according to interviews with lawyers briefed on the matter. Several banks are expected to plead guilty to resolve the investigation.

headline: Geek Squad
abstract: A history of the digital age, and of the collaborators and lone tinkerers who helped usher it in.
lead_paragraph: During the H-bomb testing frenzy of the 1950s, a RAND Corporation researcher named Paul Baran became concerned about the fragility of America’s communications networks. The era’s telephone systems required users to connect to a handful of major hubs, which the Soviets would doubtless target in the early hours of World War III. So Baran dreamed up a less vulnerable alternative: a decentralized network that resembled a vast fishnet, with an array of small nodes that were each linked to a few others. These nodes could not only receive signals but also route them along to their neighbors, thereby creating countless possible paths for data to keep flowing should part of the network be destroyed. This data would travel across the structure in tiny chunks, called “packets,” that would self-­assemble into coherent wholes upon reaching their destinations.

headline: EBay Does About-Face in Spinoff of PayPal Backed by Icahn
