headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba’s Key to Success
abstract: Alibaba brings luxury to China’s middle class. | Dollar store tug of war gets contentious. | Detroit’s bankruptcy deal hinges on two banks. | Fed slow to pop bubbles.
lead_paragraph: As the Alibaba Group prepares to go public, the Chinese company remains committed to making global e-commerce available to China’s expanding middle class, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. “The degree to which Alibaba can deliver on this promise will help determine how much the company is ultimately worth and to what extent it can open up the enormous Chinese market to both global retailers and small businesses in search of growth,” he writes.

headline: The Digital Wallet Revolution
abstract: Apple’s payment system points toward a new era of commerce.
lead_paragraph: THIS week Apple announced two new pieces of hardware, the iPhone 6 and a “smartwatch.” But as flashy as they are, neither item is as groundbreaking as a piece of software that will accompany them: a digital wallet, allowing users to eschew cash and credit cards for a quick swipe of their device at the register.

headline: Coinbase Extends Bitcoin Access to International Customers
abstract: Coinbase, one of the most popular digital wallet providers, is expanding to 13 European countries by allowing those with authorized European bank accounts to buy and sell Bitcoins in exchange for euros.
lead_paragraph: Coinbase is taking its Bitcoin services to Europe in a move that could help expand the virtual currency’s reach.

headline: Apple Pay Tries to Solve a Problem That Really Isn’t a Problem
abstract: A new mobile payment service was unveiled Tuesday, but credit cards seem to work just fine.
lead_paragraph: I recently bought a cup of coffee, but I did not have any cash handy. I used a credit card, and the result was a veritable dystopia that will surely haunt my sleep forever.

headline: Today in Small Business: Best and Worst Cities for Hispanic Entrepreneurs
abstract: Why operating cash flow is more important than net profit. Can gas pumps be smart?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Morning Agenda: Fed’s Diet Plan for Banks
abstract: Fed plans to put pressure on banks to slim down. | A closer look at Coke’s vote. | Alibaba’s roadshow begins. | Former SAC portfolio manager gets 9 years for insider trading.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve said on Monday that it planned to increase the pressure on large financial institutions to slim down, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. In testimony he will give before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, Daniel K. Tarullo, the Fed governor who oversees regulatory policies, signaled the central bank’s plan to propose special capital requirements for the largest banks that will be even higher than those demanded under international banking regulations.

headline: Braintree, Popular Payments Processor, to Accept Bitcoin
abstract: Many of Braintree’s clients are tech start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and TaskRabbit, businesses that are looking for easy ways to integrate payments into their products for a low cost.
lead_paragraph: Soon, you may be able to pay for your next Uber ride with Bitcoin.

headline: Morning Agenda: Europe’s Bond-Buying Bet
abstract: The European Central Bank will start buying loan-backed bonds. | MetLife plans to fight stricter regulation. | Puerto Rico’s electric power authority has hired a restructuring supervisor. | Defining liquidity for banks.
lead_paragraph: E.C.B. GAMBLES ON BOND-BUYING PROGRAM | Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday that the bank would soon start to buy bonds that are backed by loans made to consumers and companies, DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Alexandra Stevenson write. With the move, the central bank is gambling on a complex securities market that for several years has been struggling to get back on its feet. The purchases could make up a substantial share of the roughly 1 trillion euros, or $1.3 trillion, that Mr. Draghi implied that the bank was prepared to spend.

headline: Charles Shrem, Bitcoin Supporter, Pleads Guilty in Court
abstract: Charles Shrem said he used his company to convert dollars into Bitcoin for users of Silk Road, the now-defunct online marketplace known for selling narcotics and drug paraphernalia.
lead_paragraph: Charles Shrem, an outspoken proponent of Bitcoin who has come to symbolize the government’s crackdown on the virtual currency, pleaded guilty on Thursday to one count of aiding and abetting the operation of an unlicensed money transmitting business.

headline: Fall Arts Preview - Film
abstract: Film
lead_paragraph: Film

headline: Corrections: September 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Elections Cop Invites Mischief
abstract: The Federal Election Commission has made a travesty of its mission by giving violators permission to break the limits on spending and disclosure.
lead_paragraph: The country’s increasingly lawless political system needs a traffic cop to set clear rules and rein in violators who think nothing of breaking the spending limits. That’s supposed to be the job of the Federal Election Commission, but the agency has made a travesty of its mission, encouraging bad behavior rather than stopping it.

headline: Today in Small Business: Made in the U.S.A.
abstract: Women are opening businesses in Detroit. More workers are claiming wage theft. And the advantages of being employed by your children.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Morning Agenda: Evans Bank Under Fire
abstract: New York set to accuse Evans Bank of redlining. | Dollar General raises bid for Family Dollar. | Public pension funds staying mum on inversions. | Banks pursuing military customers.
lead_paragraph: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, is said to be conducting a broad investigation into whether banks are deliberately choking off mortgage lending to predominantly minority communities, known as “redlining,” DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. The investigation was expected to reach its first target as early as Tuesday, people briefed on the matter said, with Mr. Schneiderman’s office taking aim at Evans Bank, a regional lender whose business in the Buffalo area dates to 1920, accusing it of denying mortgages to African-Americans regardless of their credit.

headline: Top Bitcoin Proponent to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge
abstract: Charles Shrem, a leading backer of Bitcoin, is to plead to one federal count of aiding and abetting an unlicensed money transmitting business.
lead_paragraph: A prominent supporter of Bitcoin, Charles Shrem, says he will plead guilty on Thursday to resolve federal charges that he helped smooth the way for drug transactions on the online marketplace Silk Road. He is to plead in New York to one count of aiding and abetting the operation of an unlicensed money transmitting business.

headline: Hal Finney, Cryptographer and Bitcoin Pioneer, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Finney made advancing online privacy his life’s work, and he took part in the first Bitcoin transaction, when Satoshi Nakamoto sent him 10 Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: Hal Finney, a cryptographer and one of the earliest users and developers of the virtual currency Bitcoin, died on Thursday in Phoenix. He was 58.

headline: Morning Agenda: Playing the Tax Game
abstract: American companies are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes. | Dueling scholarship funds in China. | Detecting fraud in China may be riskier than committing it. | Consumers get some relief at the gas pump.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESSES WINNING THE TAX GAME | Across corporate America, companies large and small are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes, making it harder than ever for the federal government to replenish its already depleted coffers, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. As a result, business income tax revenue remains stagnant at about 2 percent of gross domestic product even as corporate profits hit records. Business taxes now make up less than 10 percent of federal revenue, down sharply from the years after World War II, when about 30 percent of federal revenue came from corporate taxes.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Problem With Passion
abstract: Stanford offers a free online course on how to build a business. Some merchants use Bitcoin A.T.M.s to attract customers. And meet a business owner who loves air travel (even turbulence).
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Morning Agenda: Amazon Scoops Up Twitch
abstract: Amazon has reached a $1.1 billion deal to buy Twitch. | Burger King aims for a fast-food empire. | Bitcoin A.T.M.s are cropping up across the globe. | A summer reading list for your inner financial geek.
lead_paragraph: Think video games are just things people play? Think again. On Monday, Amazon announced that it had reached a $1.1 billion deal to buy Twitch, the most popular website for watching people play video games, Nick Wingfield writes in The New York Times. “The deal for Twitch is the latest sign of how forms of behavior once seemingly on the fringe can, in the hands of tech entrepreneurs, turn into huge online communities in no time,” he writes. Twitch, which specializes in live videos of people playing games, has 55 million unique viewers a month globally.

headline: Election Panel Enacts Policies by Not Acting
abstract: Deadlocked votes by the Federal Election Commission have created a rapidly expanding universe of unofficial law, particularly on financial disclosure and investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The three Republican and three Democratic appointees of the Federal Election Commission had reached yet another deadlock: They would issue no advisory opinion on whether the Conservative Action Fund could accept contributions of Bitcoin, the online currency created to be untraceable.

headline: On To-Do List: Deposit Cash in Bitcoin A.T.M.
abstract: Automated machines that turn traditional money into virtual currency are cropping up, which supporters say could help the machines become as widespread as traditional bank A.T.M.s.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the A.T.M. of the future, where customers insert cash and leave with nothing.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Skills Gap
abstract: How to win on “Shark Tank.” The benefits of working at home. Should we repeal the corporate tax?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Evolving Bank Settlement Documents
abstract: Test your financial knowledge with our quiz on the “statements of fact” from three big bank settlements.
lead_paragraph: If it feels as though the billion-dollar settlements from the financial crisis are blurring together, you’re not alone.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Next Cronut
abstract: Instagram creates advertising tools for brands. How one company uses its employee handbook as a recruiting tool. Should publicly traded companies have to disclose their tax returns?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Morning Agenda: The True Cost of Bank of America’s Settlement
abstract: Bank of America’s $16.65 billion settlement may cost the bank significantly less. | Wall Street banks are digging deeper to keep top talent. | Family Dollar rejected Dollar General’s takeover bid. | A judge in New York scolded Argentina for its attempt to skirt a U.S. court ruling on bond payments.
lead_paragraph: THE TRUE COST OF BANK OF AMERICA’S DEAL | The Justice Department has collected huge sums from big banks for their role in selling troubled mortgages before the financial crisis. But in the end, the financial pain inflicted by these settlements ‒ including the $16.65 billion deal with Bank of America announced on Thursday ‒ may not be as great as these numbers suggest, DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Michael Corkery write. The actual financial burden for Bank of America, for example, may not exceed $12 billion, significantly less than the number the government trumpets.

headline: New York Today: Cool, Cool Summer
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: a look back at the mildest of summers, a rainy day, and a march on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this chilly Friday.

headline: More Comments Invited for Proposed Bitcoin Rules
abstract: New York’s financial regulator said those interested in submitting comments on new rules for virtual currencies will have until Oct. 21 to do so.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Department of Financial Services said on Thursday that it would extend by 45 days the comment period for its proposed virtual currency regulations. Those interested in submitting comments on the new rules will now have until Oct. 21.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America Nears Huge Settlement
abstract: A $16.65 billion mortgage settlement with Bank of America is set to be announced. |Scrutiny is shifting to subprime auto loans. | Dollar General questions the motives of Family Dollar’s chief executive. | Argentina has introduced a bill to sidestep a U.S. court ruling.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is set to announce a $16.65 billion settlement with Bank of America over accusations that it duped investors into buying troubled mortgage securities, DealBook’s Ben Protess, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery write, according to people briefed on the matter. The accord would be the biggest government settlement by a company in American history. Prosecutors are also preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking for which Bank of America is now paying dearly, a rare move against a senior executive at the center of the financial crisis.

headline: Chain, a Bitcoin Start-Up, Raises $9.5 Million Led by Khosla Ventures
abstract: Chain, which provides quick access to Bitcoin’s online ledger of transactions called the blockchain, has also lured several other leading venture capital firms in the latest funding round.
lead_paragraph: Another virtual currency start-up has attracted real dollars from prominent investors.

headline: Morning Agenda: Standard Chartered’s Backsliding Woes
abstract: Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating officer.
lead_paragraph: In a settlement announced on Tuesday by New York State’s financial regulator, the British bank Standard Chartered will pay a $300 million fine and suspend its dollar-clearing activities because of its failure to weed out transactions prone to money-laundering, Ben Protess and Chad Bray write in DealBook. The deal comes two years after the bank paid a combined $667 million to state and federal authorities over similar accusations. Those settlements resolved accusations that Standard Chartered, in part through its New York branch, processed transactions for Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline: Owner of Winn-Dixie and Bi-Lo Supermarkets Pulls I.P.O.
abstract: The retailer, Southeastern Grocers, didn’t give a reason in its filing for canceling the I.P.O., but it had not filed any new updates to its S.E.C. registration for months.
lead_paragraph: The owner of the Winn-Dixie and Bi-Lo supermarket chains disclosed on Tuesday that it had canceled its forthcoming initial public offering, nearly a year after the company first registered for a stock sale.

headline: Overstock to Allow International Customers to Pay in Bitcoin
abstract: The move by popular retailers like Overstock to accept Bitcoins for international transactions could lead to more widespread adoption of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: One big retailer is about the conquer the next Bitcoin frontier.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Deal Frenzy
abstract: A merger frenzy among dollar stores. | BHP Billiton plans to spin off assets into a metals and mining company. | The U.S. tax burden may not be as heavy as it seems. | Bitcoin’s price plunged on Monday to its lowest level since May.
lead_paragraph: When Dollar General offered on Monday to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, it was hoping not only to break up Family Dollar’s merger with Dollar Tree but also to strengthen its share of the low-end retail market, Michael J. de la Merced and Nelson D. Schwartz write in DealBook. “Prices at Family Dollar are kept low and its breadth of products is limited to items it can sell cheaply,” they write. “But the retailer’s success has become a symbol of the rush to cater to the working poor.”

headline: Bitcoin’s Price Falls 12%, to Lowest Value Since May
abstract: Bitcoin’s price has been noticeably falling in recent weeks after a period of relative stability, though those who trade in the virtual currency say the drop is par for the course.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | Bitcoin’s price has been known to surge, but lately it has been in a bit of a slump.

headline: Corrections: August 18, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on August 18, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Weekend Reading: Derivatives, Mortgages and Repo Markets in 2014 or 2008?
abstract: A spotlight on derivatives, risky mortgages and repo markets — practices all linked to the 2008 financial crisis — gave DealBook a certain “Groundhog Day” quality this week.
lead_paragraph: A spotlight on derivatives, risky mortgages and repo markets — practices all linked to the 2008 financial crisis — gave DealBook a certain “Groundhog Day” quality this week.

headline: Morning Agenda: Tension Mounts Over Derivatives
abstract: Regulators are pushing for changes that will affect derivatives. | G.E. is in talks to sell its appliances unit. | Coca-Cola announced that it had acquired a stake in Monster Beverage. | Bitcoin’s pop may exceed its potential.
lead_paragraph: TENSION MOUNTS OVER DERIVATIVES | Financial regulators are pushing for an arcane but crucial modification to the contracts that stand behind the $700 trillion global market for derivatives as part of their efforts to avoid the sort of systemic chaos that occurred after Lehman Brothers crashed in 2008, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Wall Street is largely resigned to the regulators’ ultimately getting their way, but it is nevertheless pressing for measures seen as protections in return.

headline: For Merchants, Bitcoin Shows More Pop Than Potential
abstract: Merchants that accept Bitcoin are trying to attract virtual currency enthusiasts. And the number of merchants has been growing.
lead_paragraph: Jason Hand had more money in his Bitcoin wallet than in his savings account.

headline: Morning Agenda: Uncertainty Over Master Limited Partnerships
abstract: Kinder Morgan’s reorganization puts master limited partnerships in question. | An arbitration panel has eased the blame on Ernst & Young for audits of Lehman Brothers. | New York prosecutors have accused payday lenders with usury. | Chiquita Brands has received a counter to its inversion plan.
lead_paragraph: When Kinder Morgan, a $100 billion empire that transports much of America’s oil and natural gas, announced on Sunday that it was abandoning the master limited partnership it helped popularize, questions emerged about what would happen to the many other such structures, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. Largely because of Kinder Morgan’s success, the partnerships have become increasingly popular for energy companies. The structure allows them to pass all profits along to their investors as dividends and pay no corporate taxes, though the investors are subject to taxes on the distributions.

headline: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Warns on Bitcoins
abstract: The agency issued its first consumer advisory on virtual currencies and said it would begin accepting complaints about such issues or companies.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is in the cross hairs of another federal agency.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Libertarianism’s Prospects
abstract: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the rise of libertarianism. Here, he discusses the movement’s prospects.
lead_paragraph: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the rise of libertarianism. Draper is the author of ”When the Tea Party Came to Town.” His last article for the magazine was about Wendy Davis.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America’s Big Mortgage Settlement
abstract: Bank of America offered the U.S. the biggest settlement in history. | T-Mobile taunted Sprint after a takeover plan fell apart. | Why Walgreen shied away from an inversion in its deal for Alliance Boots. | Time Warner was silent on 21st Century Fox’s takeover attempt during its earnings call on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: BANK OF AMERICA NEARS DEAL WITH JUSTICE DEPT. | After months of talks, Bank of America suddenly caved in to the government, agreeing to the largest single federal settlement in the history of corporate America, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. The tentative deal ‒ which would cost the bank more than $16 billion to settle investigations into its sale of toxic mortgage securities in the run-up to the financial crisis ‒ came together last week after an unexpected ruling in another Bank of America case that undercut the bank’s negotiating leverage.

headline: Has the ‘Libertarian Moment’ Finally Arrived?
abstract: Rand Paul and the libertarians could win young voters for the G.O.P. — if the party doesn’t shut them down.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s say Ron Paul is Nirvana,” said Kennedy, the television personality and former MTV host, by way of explaining the sort of politician who excites libertarians like herself. “Like, the coolest, most amazing thing to come along in years, and the songs are nebulous but somehow meaningful, and the lead singer kills himself to preserve the band’s legacy.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation Seeks More Time to Address Virtual Currency Rules
abstract: The foundation said in a letter to New York’s top financial regulator that “the Bitcoin community is not well-versed in New York financial services law.”
lead_paragraph: Big-name Bitcoin supporters are stepping up the pressure on New York State’s top financial regulator to extend the comment period for the state’s new virtual currency rules.

headline: Wealth Managers Enlist Spy Tools to Map Portfolios
abstract: Companies like Addepar are using data-filtering techniques honed at spy agencies to help track and value clients’ diverse holdings.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Some of the engineers who used to help the Central Intelligence Agency solve problems have moved on to another challenge: determining the value of every conceivable investment in the world.

headline: Where Tech Is Taking Us: A Conversation With Intel’s Genevieve Bell
abstract: Genevieve Bell, an anthropologist who is also an Intel Fellow, looks at how tech changes the world, and vice versa. She is convinced we are at a rare period of social change, with the explosion of digital intelligence into every part of our lives.
lead_paragraph: Genevieve Bell grew up among Aboriginal people in Australia, taught anthropology at Stanford and for the past 16 years has worked for Intel. It all shows in her lively mind: Ask her the time and, along with the hour, you might hear about how native Australian languages fuse the words for past, present and land, along with the history of the mechanical clock and how that determined people’s feelings about robots.

headline: ‘New Hells’
abstract: In a world laid bare to technological scrutiny, a retreat to the psychological dark side seems like a smart idea, and that’s where “New Hells” goes.
lead_paragraph: In a world laid bare to technological scrutiny, a retreat to the psychological dark side seems like a smart idea, and that’s where “New Hells”, organized by Isaac Lyles, associate director of Derek Eller Gallery, goes. Declaredly pro-weird, the show is a maze of inscrutable references but has nicely sticky visual texture that keeps us looking even when we’re not sure what’s going on.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of America and U.S. Far Apart on Deal
abstract: Bank of America and the Justice Department are still far apart on a mortgage settlement. | Argentina has found a relentless foe in Paul E. Singer. | G.E.’s Synchrony Financial begins trading on Thursday. | BNP Paribas posts a record quarterly loss.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America and federal prosecutors have accelerated their negotiations to resolve an investigation into the bank’s sale of troubled mortgage securities before the financial crisis, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. But the two sides remain far apart on crucial issues, and a settlement remained elusive late on Wednesday, even after the bank raised its offer.

headline: Wikipedia Begins Taking Donations in Bitcoin
abstract: The nonprofit organization that operates Wikipedia said that it had been asked to accept Bitcoin and that those requests, as well as recent guidelines from the I.R.S., persuaded it to accept the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin has found another taker.

headline: Morning Agenda: Profit Soars at Steven Cohen’s Firm
abstract: Steven Cohen’s revamped firm is still minting profit. | Argentina appears headed for its second default in 13 years. | A former adviser’s previous attempt to sell Trulia has reaped rewards. | Barclays swings to a profit.
lead_paragraph: Three months after his once-powerful hedge fund entered a guilty plea to insider trading charges, Steven A. Cohen is continuing to make an astounding amount of money from trading stocks and bonds, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein writes. His rechristened firm, Point72 Asset Management, which manages $9 billion to $10 billion of his personal fortune, is proving to be nearly as profitable as his former hedge fund, generating a profit of nearly $1 billion, over the first six months of this year. In 2013, SAC Capital Advisors’ last year as a hedge fund, Mr. Cohen personally made about $2.3 billion.

headline: Proposed Rules Expose Rifts Among Bitcoin Enthusiasts
abstract: Bitcoin supporters have had a mixed reaction on whether New York’s planned rules will help legitimize the virtual currency or thwart innovation.
lead_paragraph: A new front has opened in the battle over Bitcoin.

headline: Today in Small Business: Zico Versus Vita Coco
abstract: Why this will be an unusually busy week for the economy. Is Babson a better deal than Harvard?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Can Reddit Grow Up?
abstract: Efforts by the freewheeling online community to monetize without driving away its 114 million monthly users will require appealing to advertisers without sacrificing values like personal data privacy.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding nine years ago, Reddit has stuck to its own weird guns.

headline: Today in Small Business: A Hamster Wheel for Cats
abstract: Also, a Yelp for marijuana dispensaries. And an Uber for retail deliveries.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Rand Paul Talks Tech
abstract: The libertarian senator told a group of young, conservative techies that tech will make obsolete much government regulation. He told them to tailor the message: Not no government, just minimal government, maximum tech.
lead_paragraph: A successful libertarian politician is a creature of nuance. After all, he is drawing a government salary to get rid of government, without confusing his audience.

headline: Morning Agenda: Chinese Elite Tied to Alibaba I.P.O.
abstract: Alibaba’s I.P.O. could be a bonanza for the scions of Chinese leaders. | The market for subprime auto loans is booming. | Dell shareholders’ appraisal efforts hit a snag. | AbbVie has sealed a $54 billion deal for Shire.
lead_paragraph: When the Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group completed a $7.6 billion deal in 2012 to buy back half of Yahoo’s stake in the company, it raised part of the money by selling shares to select investors, notably China’s sovereign wealth fund and three prominent Chinese investment firms, Michael Forsythe writes in DealBook. What it did not detail was the deep political connections of the investment firms, Boyu Capital, Citic Capital Holdings and CDB Capital, the China Development Bank’s private investment arm.

headline: Dell Begins Accepting Bitcoin
abstract: As Bitcoin has become more mainstream, merchants may now be embracing digital money to reduce payment processing fees and make purchases easier for already-loyal customers.
lead_paragraph: Another well-known company is embracing digital money.

headline: Morning Agenda: AbbVie Wins Deal for Shire
abstract: AbbVie agreed on Friday to buy the Irish drug maker Shire for around $54 billion. | Alibaba has pushed its I.P.O. to September. | Growth in wealth management bolstered Morgan Stanley’s second-quarter profit. | New York State’s top financial regulator has proposed regulations for virtual currency companies.
lead_paragraph: ABBVIE CLINCHES $54 BILLION DEAL FOR SHIRE | The pharmaceutical giant AbbVie agreed on Friday to buy the Irish drug maker Shire for around $54 billion, the biggest takeover deal so far this year, Mark Scott writes in DealBook. The deal will allow AbbVie, based outside Chicago, to reincorporate in Britain and reduce its tax bill, representing the largest ever inversion as United States companies rush to pursue the financial advantages of moving overseas, even as lawmakers move to crack down on the increasingly popular maneuver.

headline: Student Crossword | Currency Around the World
abstract: Test your knowledge of the international currencies by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of the currency of countries around the world by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Bitcoin Regulation in New York
abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, proposed a “BitLicense” plan, which includes rules on consumer protection, the prevention of money laundering and cybersecurity.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, proposed a “BitLicense” plan, which includes rules on consumer protection, the prevention of money laundering and cybersecurity.

headline: New York Proposes First State Regulations for Bitcoin
abstract: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, has taken a big step to bring Bitcoin and other virtual currencies under his purview.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s top financial regulator has taken a big step to bring Bitcoin and other virtual currencies under its purview.

abstract: The story behind that Comcast customer-service call. Why it’s getting even harder to run a restaurant. Do we need a corporate income tax?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

abstract: A retail store with no sales staff. The hottest start-ups of 2014. And why are bowling alleys vanishing?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Gwen Stefani Returns to the Runway, Ellen DeGeneres’s Lifestyle Line and Kendall Jenner’s Couture Debut
abstract: Plus, Maison Martin Margiela’s franc statement, Apple’s latest fashion-world hire and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: How to Read the Polls in This Year’s Midterms
abstract: It will be trickier than usual, because of changes in polling and the specific states involved.
lead_paragraph: With four months to go until this year’s midterm elections, perhaps the only thing clear about the fight for the Senate is that it will pose challenges to public polling.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paying Employees After a Fire
abstract: Optimism falls. Potato-salad copycats emerge on Kickstarter. And approval rates at big banks hit a post-recession high.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Morning Agenda: Prosecutors’ Perfect Streak Ends
abstract: Prosecutors’ winning streak in insider trading cases ends. | Citigroup is said to be near a settlement over mortgage investments. | Medtronic’s shareholders to pay a big price in deal to acquire Covidien. | Media and tech moguls gather in Sun Valley.
lead_paragraph: Since the government’s crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry became public in 2009 with the arrest of Raj Rajaratnam, federal prosecutors under Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, had secured 85 insider trading convictions and guilty pleas without one defeat. But on Tuesday, that perfect streak came to an end, Matthew Goldstein, Rachel Abrams and Ben Protess write in DealBook. After just under four hours of deliberation, a federal jury found Rengan Rajaratnam ‒ the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of insider trading in 2011 ‒ not guilty of conspiracy to commit insider trading with his older brother.

headline: Today in Small Business: Saving the Naked Bean
abstract: BlaBlaCar. Extortion notices. What to do when co-workers fight. And the economy adds 288,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Daily Report: Winner of Bitcoin Auction Seeks to Increase Currency’s Use in Emerging Markets
abstract: Through a partnership with the Bitcoin exchange start-up Vaurum, the auction’s winner, the venture capitalist Tim Draper, intends to make the coins available for use in emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: When the government auctioned nearly 30,000 Bitcoins on Friday, many bidders were looking for a bargain, hoping to buy the virtual currency at a discount and flip it later for a short-term profit.

headline: Morning Agenda: When the C.E.O. Gets Sick
abstract: Jamie Dimon is the latest leader to disclose an illness. | The venture capitalist Tim Draper won the Bitcoin auction. | A judge has narrowed the insider trading case against Rengan Rajaratnam. | Tyson has reached a deal for Hillshire.
lead_paragraph: Corporate leaders from Steven P. Jobs to Warren E. Buffett and now Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, have wrestled with how ‒ or whether ‒ to go public about health problems, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Julie Creswell write in DealBook. How much to disclose, and when, involves delicate corporate and personal decisions for which there are few hard rules. Executives have no real legal obligation to tell the world they are sick.

headline: Today in Small Business: Speed-Dating
abstract: Inside a marijuana dispensary. Retailers accepting Bitcoin. And how to give compliments at work.

headline: Winner of Bitcoin Auction, Tim Draper, Plans to Expand Currency’s Use

headline: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Chief Has ‘Curable’ Cancer
abstract: Jamie Dimon has throat cancer. | Puerto Rico’s power utility is struggling to pay its debts. | A single bidder won a Bitcoin auction by the U.S. Marshals Service. | Pershing Square has hired Credit Suisse as an adviser in its fight with Allergan.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was “curable.” Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the “original site” and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as “excellent.”

headline: Single Winner of All Bitcoins in U.S. Auction
abstract: The United States Marshals Service said on Tuesday that the nearly 30,000 Bitcoins in its auction had gone to one bidder, but it did not identify the winner or disclose the winning bid.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshals Service announced on Tuesday that one bidder had won all of the nearly 30,000 Bitcoins auctioned on Friday.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Road to BNP’s Guilty Plea
abstract: BNP’s guilty plea is the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks. | Walgreen is looking to move abroad in a so-called inversion. | Who won the Bitcoin auction? | A group of New York hedge funds have backed Argentina into a corner.
lead_paragraph: State and federal authorities announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas on Monday for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. BNP’s agreement to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty ends months of arm-twisting by French officials. It is also the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which began with a bus bombing two decades ago and a grieving New Jersey father’s quest for justice, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook.

headline: After Bitcoin Auction, Winning Bidders Remain Elusive
abstract: As the United States Marshals Service began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.
lead_paragraph: Since Friday, when the United States Marshals Service auctioned off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins, investors and Bitcoin enthusiasts alike have been eagerly awaiting the results. As the agency began notifying winning and losing participants late on Monday afternoon, many in the Bitcoin world were still trying to figure out who won and the what they paid.

headline: Weekend Reading: Advancing on Bank Penalties
abstract: With a guilty plea and fine expected for BNP Paribas, Wall Street’s attention now turns to two big civil investigations into the mortgage crisis.

headline: Morning Agenda: $8.9 Billion Penalty for BNP
abstract: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty. | Brokerage firms shunned Barclays’ trading pool on Thursday. | The federal government is auctioning off nearly 30,000 Bitcoins. | Argentina appeared to defy a judge’s order on debt payments.
lead_paragraph: BNP TO PLEAD GUILTY AND PAY $8.9 BILLION FINE  |  BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. The plea deal, which authorities hope to announce on Monday, will include a statement of facts that outlines how BNP, France’s largest bank, hid the names of Sudanese clients when processing transactions through its American operations.

headline: Tally of Cyber Extortion Attacks on Tech Companies Grows
abstract: A flood of extortion attempts against web start-ups that began earlier this year appears to be getting worse. Evernote, Feedly, Moz and, this week, Move, an online real estate service, have been targeted in the last month.
lead_paragraph: Tech start-ups continue to get hit by extortion attempts from cybercriminals who aim to shut down their systems until companies pay their ransom.

headline: Morning Agenda: Detroit’s New Pension Plan
abstract: Detroit and its unions have negotiated a cost-cutting hybrid pension plan. | Markit shares are set begin trading. | A British hedge funds is breaking ties with its charitable arm. | The Justice Department’s cases against two European banks have raised questions of a double standard.
lead_paragraph: In the face of Detroit’s tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments, Mary Williams Walsh writes in DealBook. One of the most closely watched issues of the case is whether government pensions can be legally cut in bankruptcy. Now, Detroit has introduced a new plan with the cooperation of its unions, which have been among the most vocal opponents of cutbacks.

headline: Morning Agenda: Argentina’s Court Loss Buoys Creditors
abstract: The Supreme Court hands Argentina two defeats. | A study puts insider trading suspicions into hard numbers. | Medtronic’s deal for Covidien has reignited the debate over inversions. | Alibaba reveals more information in an amended I.P.O. prospectus.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday handed two major defeats to the government of Argentina, which has been fighting with New York hedge funds over bonds that the country defaulted on in 2001. Along with putting Argentina at risk of another default, the setbacks could also make it harder in the future for a financially troubled country to cut a deal with its creditors to reduce its debt load, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Argentina had asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court’s ruling that had required the country to pay back defaulted bonds held by the litigating hedge funds, known as holdouts.

lead_paragraph: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group on Monday publicly disclosed the names of all 27 individuals who will make up the company’s select inner circle in an amended initial public offering prospectus, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The individuals, led by a company founder, Jack Ma, will essentially control the online market operator through their ability to nominate a majority of directors.

headline: Food Fight
abstract: Hillshire Brands finds itself in the middle of a bidding war. | Some colleges are offering a real-world experience of philanthropy. | Realty investors are flocking to Spain. | Dish Network said it would allow its customers to make payments in Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: FOOD FIGHT  |  A week ago, many shareholders of Hillshire Brands were complaining about its planned acquisition of Pinnacle Foods, the maker of Birds Eye frozen vegetables. But in the last week, Hillshire ‒ the home of its namesake lunch meats, Ball Park hot dogs and Jimmy Dean sausages ‒ has gone from would-be pursuer to pursued, David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. On Thursday, Tyson Foods bid $6.8 billion for the company, only two days after a $6.4 billion proposal by Pilgrim’s Pride, one of the country’s big poultry producers.

headline: Dish Network Says It Will Accept Bitcoin
abstract: The satellite television provider announced on Thursday that it will begin allowing its 14 million subscribers to pay in Bitcoin later this year.
lead_paragraph: Most of Dish Network’s 14 million subscribers are probably not Bitcoin users. But that will not stop the company from accepting payments in the virtual currency later this year.

headline: New York Today: Manhattanhenge

headline: Valeant Turns Up the Heat
abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has raised its takeover bid for Allergan. | An offer by Pilgrim’s Pride sets up a potential battle over Hillshire Brands. | Pimco has brought back a former top executive. | Fabrice Tourre said that he would not appeal his case in higher court.
lead_paragraph: VALEANT RAISES BID FOR ALLERGAN  |  Valeant Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday raised its takeover bid for Allergan, turning up the heat in its pursuit of the Botox maker, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The new offer comes on the heels of a separate deal in which Nestlé will buy the sales rights to some of Valeant’s skin care products for $1.4 billion. It also arrives a day after Allergan unveiled a more pointed defense against the takeover bid, questioning the sustainability of its unwanted suitor’s business model and stock price.

headline: Faking Cultural Literacy
abstract: Our cultural canon is determined by whatever gets the most clicks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I CAN’T help it. Every few weeks, my wife mentions the latest book her book club is reading, and no matter what it is, whether I’ve read it or not, I offer an opinion of the work, based entirely on ... what, exactly? Often, these are books I’ve not even read a review or essay about, yet I freely hold forth on the grandiosity of Cheryl Strayed or the restrained sentimentality of Edwidge Danticat. These data motes are gleaned, apparently, from the ether — or, more realistically, from various social media feeds.

headline: Big Breaks for Banks
abstract: Banks continue to stay in business after being convicted of felons. | Pinterest raises more money. | Investors reject Chipotle chiefs’ pay plan. | Detroit’s bankruptcy deadline may be missed.
lead_paragraph: BIG BREAKS FOR BANKS  |  If, as expected, two banking giants ‒ Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas ‒ plead guilty to criminal charges in the next few weeks, they will probably pay large fines and officially be felons, Floyd Norris writes in the High & Low Finance column. But, he asks, does it matter that these will be criminal, not civil, punishments? The issue is not that banks may be “too big to jail,” but that, big or small, banks and other corporations are “too inanimate to jail,” Mr. Norris writes.

headline: AT&T Pursues DirecTV
abstract: AT&T is in talks to buy DirecTV. | Pfizer’s deal for AstraZeneca raises a public policy red flag. | Allergan rejects Valeant’s bid and focuses on its own strategy. | Annual meetings of Wall Street banks give shareholders a chance to air their grievances.
lead_paragraph: AT&T is in talks to buy DirecTV for at least $50 billion, and the two sides are said to be actively working toward an announcement, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. If the deal is completed, it would give AT&T, the country’s second-largest wireless carrier, control of the country’s largest satellite television provider, a move that would further reshape the already changing telecommunications and television industries.

headline: BNP Paribas and Credit Suisse Seek Leniency
abstract: BNP Paribas and Credit Suisse ask authorities in the United States to go easy. | Pfizer goes online to defend its bid for AstraZeneca. | Timothy F. Geithner’s book, “Stress Test,” comes out today. | Morgan Stanley is king in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Facing the threat of criminal charges, BNP Paribas and Credit Suisse are imploring authorities in the United States for leniency, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. To avoid fallout from pleading guilty, the banks are said to have made last-ditch appeals to prosecutors and regulators in recent weeks.

lead_paragraph: Jared Polis may be the first politician to accept campaign donations in Bitcoin.

headline: Apple’s New Tune
abstract: Apple is said to be in talks to buy Beats Electronics for $3.2 billion. | Ad agencies call off their $35 billion merger. | Companies are weighing moving abroad to escape the United States corporate tax rate. | Timothy F. Geithner wants to be understood.
lead_paragraph: APPLE IN TALKS TO BUY BEATS  |  Apple is said to be in discussions to buy Beats Electronics, the company behind the popular Beats by Dr. Dre headphones, for $3.2 billion, Ben Sisario, Brian X. Chen and David Gelles write in DealBook. The deal, which would also include the new Beats Music streaming service, would be the biggest acquisition in Apple’s history and could suggest an effort to shake up its approach to digital music.

headline: Election Commission Votes to Allow Bitcoin Donations
abstract: The commissioners, in a unanimous ruling, also set a cap on donations of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Election Commission on Thursday voted to allow political committees to accept Bitcoin donations and outlined the ways that the virtual currency can be used by federally regulated campaigns.

headline: Awaiting Alibaba’s I.P.O.
abstract: Chatter ahead of Alibaba’s I.P.O. | A look at why only one top banker has gone to jail after the financial crisis. | A federal regulator says banks erred on troubled mortgages. | Facebook changes its rules for log-ins.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant that is about to go public in the United States, is said to be in talks with its Alipay payment affiliate about regaining a stake in the business, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The two sides have been in talks for nearly a year and a half, and no agreement is imminent. In any case, the possibility that Alibaba could be formally reunited with its payment division would be of great interest to the company’s future shareholders.

headline: Resisting the 911’s Gravitational Pull
abstract: The Porsche Cayman may never beat its big brother, the 911, but it’s an appealing choice among midengine coupes, and midengine coupes are the stuff of greatness.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been keeping up with Neil deGrasse Tyson’s “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey” on Fox, you may be familiar with the concept of the multiverse — the idea that our universe is just one among a potentially infinite number of others. If true, there could be some alternate universe almost just like ours, but slightly different.

headline: Companies Back Initiative to Support OpenSSL and Other Open-Source Projects

headline: Big Pharma’s Deal Bonanza

lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical industry is regaining its swagger, Michael J. de la Merced, David Gelles and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook. On Tuesday alone, pharmaceutical companies announced $74 billion worth of potential deals, including an unconventional $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, and a flurry of swaps and sales between Novartis of Switzerland and GlaxoSmithKline of Britain. More deals in the cash-rich industry are expected.
