abstract: The market for initial public offerings has reached levels not seen in the United States in years. | Steven A. Cohen’s minder has been selected. | One of Citigroup’s stalwarts will lead the bank’s preparations for the Fed stress test over the next year. | The chief executive of Mozilla has resigned.
lead_paragraph: BIG RUSH FOR I.P.O.S  |  Since 1999, the stock market has waxed and waned, but the business of initial public offerings is bustling once again, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. GrubHub, an online food-ordering company, and IMS Health, a big provider of prescription data, are just two of the latest companies hoping to seize upon investor demand for new stock offerings. At the same time, they are hoping to avoid the stumbles that have plagued a few high-profile issuers in recent weeks, including King Digital Entertainment, the maker of Candy Crush Saga.

headline: Corrections: April 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on April 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Tech Start-Ups Are Targets of Ransom Cyberattacks
abstract: Several web companies have recently been hit with attacks that can knock them offline using a flood of traffic unless they pay ransoms in Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: Scott Heiferman and Gary Burns had less than four minutes to decide whether to pay up or go down.

headline: Shadows Over Citigroup
abstract: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into fraud involving Citigroup’s Mexican unit. | Blythe Masters, the head of JPMorgan Chase’s commodities unit, is leaving the bank. | China’s answer to Wall Street. | Rendering a strong case against Bank of America weak.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroup’s Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the giant bank, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook. The investigation, overseen by the F.B.I. and prosecutors from the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan, is focusing in part on whether holes in the bank’s internal controls contributed to the fraud in Mexico.

headline: How to Explain Bitcoin to Your Mom!
abstract: A guide to the system of virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: A guide to the system of virtual currency.

headline: Stemming Departures at SAC
abstract: SAC Capital Advisors is pressing traders to sign two-year contracts. | The next three decades may upend the basic tenets of finance. | Efforts are underway to make payment systems safer. | Goldman Sachs weighs sale of market-making unit.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen is putting pressure on his traders to try to keep his once-powerful hedge fund together as it awaits a judge’s decision next week on its guilty plea to securities fraud charges, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. Mr. Cohen is aiming to curtail a slow but steady departure of top portfolio managers by pressing those who remain to sign two-year contracts that would bind them to him until the end of 2016.

headline: Two Dollar Bill Is Oddity, but Some Love the Tender
abstract: One billion are in circulation, but it has always lagged in popularity behind the $1 bill.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Bitcoin. There is another uncommon tender angling for a spotlight, or in this case, a comeback: the $2 bill.

headline: A Revolution in Money
abstract: Futurists predict a revolution in the tenets of finance in the coming decades, similar to the changes that have been sweeping the information and telecommunications industries.
lead_paragraph: Imagine it’s 2040.

headline: Where’s Satoshi Nakamoto?
abstract: Bitcoin was created by an anonymous computer programmer, or group of computer programmers, known only as “Satoshi Nakamoto.” See if you can spot him here.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin was created by an anonymous computer programmer, or group of computer programmers, known only as “Satoshi Nakamoto.” See if you can spot him here.

headline: To Instill Love of Bitcoin, Backers Work to Make It Safe
abstract: Bitcoin’s future may not rely on stabilizing its price swings or signing up more merchants to accept the virtual currency. Rather, it may rely on its image.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO – BITCOIN’S future may not rely on stabilizing its price swings or signing up more merchants to accept the virtual currency. Rather, it may rely on its image.

headline: Essay: The Real Competition to Virtual Currency
abstract: Bitcoin and its peers have so far failed to gain wide acceptance because the current monetary system works very well and is itself adaptable.
lead_paragraph: BITCOIN enthusiasts may want to study a satirical etching, published in 1792, that is now in a collection at London’s National Portrait Gallery. In one half, titled “French Liberty,” an emaciated French revolutionary gnaws on raw onions. In the other, “British Slavery,” a corpulent Englishman feasts on a giant slab of meat. The etching’s message — that a revolution is a farce if it fails to provide the basics — hangs uneasily over the world of virtual currencies.

headline: Today in Small Business: Erosion
abstract: What small businesses can learn from Amazon Prime. Customer-service lessons from Four Seasons Hotels. And an Instagram meme called, “Baby Suiting.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Consumers Are Still Seeing Seams in the Mobile Wallet
abstract: Despite a proliferation of digital payment technology from Google, Square, Venmo and others, most smartphone users are still spending the old-fashioned way.
lead_paragraph: LIBBY CATHEY and her sorority sisters fumbled with pesos as they split the bill at Señor Frog’s in Cancún, Mexico, over spring break last month.

headline: Taking On Flash Trading
abstract: Few on Wall Street want to miss out on the conversation about high-frequency trading. | Recent technologies are calling into the question the future of money. | A look at Russian influence in London’s financial markets. | Ares Management to go public.
lead_paragraph: In his new book, “Flash Boys,” Michael Lewis describes how high-frequency trading works, highlighting a system on Wall Street that has allowed certain professional investors to pay hundreds of millions of dollars a year to locate their computer servers close to stock exchanges so they can make trades milliseconds ahead of everyone else. “There is only one problem with Mr. Lewis’s tale: He reserves blame for the wrong villains,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: Makers of Bitcoin A.T.M.’s See a Not-Quite-Cashless Future
abstract: Several companies have recognized that for the foreseeable future, even virtual currency users still need cash, and they have developed machines that allow users to buy and sell Bitcoin for cash.
lead_paragraph: IN addition to the Glocks and Remingtons that have long been available at Central Texas Gun Works, customers can now buy something new: Bitcoin.

headline: Starting an Overdue Conversation About Money
abstract: If nothing else, virtual currencies like Bitcoin have raised questions about the nature of money and how it might be evolving.
lead_paragraph: THERE is no end to the disagreements about the importance and usefulness of the upstart virtual currency Bitcoin.

headline: The ‘Dewey Seven’ Pleas, Unsealed
abstract: The pleas of seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf have been unsealed. | Comcast’s chief executive is looking beyond cable. | Is Facebook too big to care? | A lawyer takes on fiduciary failures. | The author Michael Lewis is taking aim at high-speed traders.
lead_paragraph: Seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme to manipulate the law firm’s finances came from very different backgrounds than many of the high-powered lawyers at the once-prominent New York firm, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. The employees’ guilty pleas were unsealed on Thursday and Friday, revealing that none of the former employees was a lawyer and just one was a certified public accountant.

headline: Weekend Reading: March Madness, Wall St. Edition II
abstract: This week we look at some second, and third round matches in the Wall street edition of March Madness.
lead_paragraph: This week we look at some second, and third round matches in the Wall street edition of March Madness.

headline: Bitcoin at a ‘Fork in the Road,’ Analyst Says
abstract: Steven Englander of Citigroup says that I.R.S. decision ends some Bitcoin mythologies and possibly paves the way for a “$coin.”
lead_paragraph: The guidance that the Internal Revenue Service provided on Tuesday that  Bitcoin should be treated as property rather than as currency for tax purposes has prompted a fair amount of commentary, including a Standard Deduction column by DealBook’s Victor Fleischer.

headline: A Failure for Citigroup
abstract: The Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s capital plans. | The chief executive of King Digital Entertainment remained optimistic after shares of his company fell nearly 16 percent on their first day of public trading. | Corporations are pressing law firms to tighten their cyber security. | Reverse mortgages are stinging heirs.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP FAILS FED STRESS TEST  |  For the second time in three years, the Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s plans to manage its capital, an embarrassing blow that could derail the plans of Michael Corbat, the bank’s chief executive, to rehabilitate the bank, Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. Citigroup was the only one of the nation’s top five banks that failed to persuade the Fed to bless its plans for shareholder payouts.

headline: Today in Small Business: Personalized Shopping
abstract: And will President Obama’s new rules for overtime pay hurt the very people it is supposed to help?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Taxes Won’t Kill Bitcoin, but Tax Reporting Might
abstract: In the Standard Deduction column, Victor Fleischer examines how the I.R.S. expects individuals and businesses to treat Bitcoins for tax purposes.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is a digital representation of value, not a real currency, according to the latest pronouncement from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Start-Up Unveils Bitcoin Payments Product
abstract: The payment systems product from the start-up Circle Internet Financial allows consumers to deposit dollars into an account, which converts the money into Bitcoin and stores it remotely.
lead_paragraph: While some restaurants, bars and coffee shops accept the virtual currency Bitcoin, it still exists largely in the province of speculators. One start-up, Circle Internet Financial, is trying to push Bitcoin into mainstream commerce.

headline: Facebook’s $2 Billion Deal for Oculus
abstract: Facebook to buy Oculus, a maker of a virtual reality headset. | A likely heir is leaving JPMorgan Chase. | The maker of Candy Crush is set to trade on the N.Y.S.E. | The Murdochs take a step in succession planning.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise move, Facebook announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $2 billion agreement to buy Oculus VR, the maker of a virtual reality headset, in a bet that technology commonly associated with science fiction can help eventually turn social networking into an immersive 3-D experience, Nick Wingfield and Vindu Goel write in The New York Times. The announcement comes just over a month after Facebook made waves by revealing it would buy the mobile messaging app WhatsApp for up to $19 billion.

headline: Mt. Gox Seeks Advice From Japanese Police
abstract: It is unclear whether the Tokyo police will start a formal investigation into Mt. Gox, the Bitcoin exchange that filed for bankruptcy last month.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO – Mt. Gox, the Bitcoin exchange based here that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, said on Wednesday that it had asked the Japanese police for advice on Bitcoins worth half a billion dollars that the company claims were stolen by hackers.

headline: Wall St. rallies as consumers perk up
abstract: Summary: A jump in consumer confidence to a six-year high helps Wall Street stop losing streak; new home sales fall again but old home prices rise; IRS says bitcoin should be taxed as property.  Conway G. Gittens reports.
lead_paragraph: Summary: A jump in consumer confidence to a six-year high helps Wall Street stop losing streak; new home sales fall again but old home prices rise; IRS says bitcoin should be taxed as property.  Conway G. Gittens reports.

headline: I.R.S. Takes a Position on Bitcoin: It’s Property
abstract: Some financial experts view the move as a way to push Bitcoin away from the fringes and into the mainstream financial system.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:53 p.m. | The Internal Revenue Service may have just taken some of the fun out of Bitcoin. But that may mean that the virtual currency is growing up.

headline: Today in Small Business: From the Web to Bricks and Mortar
abstract: Getting people to read your emails. How G.M. is using social media to manage its reputation. Are you really as busy as you say you are?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Top JPMorgan Banker Is Departing
abstract: One of JPMorgan’s top deal makers in China is retiring. | Herbalife is allowing Carl C. Icahn to nominate three more board representatives. | Regulatory changes have been slow to take hold at credit rating agencies. | Pimco has been attracting attention for the wrong reasons. | The Silk Road case began with a hunt for “John Doe.”
lead_paragraph: Fang Fang, one of JPMorgan Chase’s top deal makers in China and a focus of the United States government’s investigation into the bank’s hiring practices in China, is resigning, Neil Gough writes in DealBook. Mr. Fang announced his decision in an internal memo sent to employees on Monday.

headline: Silk Road Case Began With Hunt for a John Doe
abstract: The criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht began quietly with an indictment filed in a Maryland courthouse against an unidentified individual five months before the authorities made an arrest.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht, the man who federal prosecutors contend is the mastermind behind the notorious Silk Road online marketplace for illegal drugs and hacked credit card numbers, began quietly with an indictment filed in a Maryland courthouse against an unidentified individual five months before the authorities made an arrest.

headline: Weekend Reading: March Madness, Wall St. Edition
abstract: A number of sides are facing off in our financial coverage of the past week. Since we’ve already blown our NCAA brackets, lets try out the concept with Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: A number of sides are facing off in our financial coverage of the past week. Since we’ve already blown our NCAA college basketball brackets, lets try out the concept with the news from Wall Street.

headline: Mt. Gox Says It Found Missing Bitcoin Worth About $116 Million
abstract: Mt. Gox, the Tokyo-based Bitcoin exchange that collapsed and filed for bankruptcy last month, said it had found 200,000 Bitcoins that were held in an “old-format wallet,” or digital storage file.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | The seemingly miraculous discovery of about $116 million in missing Bitcoin, or 200,000 coins, late Thursday underscored the rickety early infrastructure that the digital currency is still trying to overcome.

headline: Joining the 11-Digit Valuation Club
abstract: The couch-surfing company Airbnb is close to raising a funding round that would give it a valuation of more than $10 billion. | The chief executive of Time Warner Cable is set to receive nearly $80 million in severance payment. | The Fed released the results of its latest stress test — and all but one of the 30 banks under review passed. | Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to start a $2 billion hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: AIRBNB NEARS $10 BILLION VALUATION  |  The couch-surfing website Airbnb was once selling cereal boxes with presidential candidates’ faces just to stay afloat. Now, the company is close to joining a rarefied group of start-ups: the 11-digit valuation club, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook.

headline: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: Hong Kong entrepreneurs see a lucrative future in virtual money.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong entrepreneurs see a lucrative future in virtual money.

headline: Questioning the Leverage Ratio
abstract: The New York Fed president’s concerns are said to have delayed a banking rule. | Questions about why seven Dewey & LeBoeuf employees who have pleaded guilty have not been identified. | The Federal Reserve is continuing to taper its bond-buying program. | JPMorgan Chase sells its physical commodities unit.
lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis, William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has made significant changes to bolster the bank’s supervision efforts. But now, some regulators are blaming him for holding up a proposed rule to make banks safer, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. Mr. Dudley is said to have privately expressed his concerns to senior Fed officials in Washington about the rule, known as the supplementary leverage ratio, frustrating other regulators who see it as a centerpiece of a financial system overhaul.

headline: Daily Report: Entrepreneurs in Hong Kong Place Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing number of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene, Alan Wong reports.

headline: In Hong Kong, Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

headline: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

headline: Can You Trust ‘Secure’ Messaging Apps?
abstract: Messaging apps and security are two of the hottest topics in tech. But can you trust the wave of supposedly secure messaging services coming out now? The New York Times’s Molly Wood talks to an expert.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially a post-Snowden and post-WhatsApp world, and my inbox is filled with pitches from companies promoting their secure messaging apps. But can you trust them?

headline: More Scrutiny for Payday Lenders
abstract: A state by state battle against payday lenders is heating up. | Institutional investors join with activist hedge funds in the push for corporate control. | A court ruling calls into question whether an investment bank should pay the bill in a legal settlement while directors escape with nary a scratch. | The New York attorney general widens an inquiry of high-frequency trading.
lead_paragraph: The battle is heating up against payday lenders and their practice of offering fast money to borrowers so desperate for cash that they are often willing to accept it at almost any terms, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline: Fortress, Benchmark and Ribbit  Buy Stake in Pantera Bitcoin
abstract: The partnership represents a significant step in the push to move Bitcoin into the financial mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent investment firms are joining forces to buy stakes in one of the biggest Bitcoin operations in the world.

headline: Taking Aim at an Anonymous Blogger
abstract: David Einhorn’s case against the website Seeking Alpha could affect the future of business journalism. | Foreign investors in Russia are beginning to sound the alarm. | A boutique advisory firm played an important role in the Vodafone-Ono deal. | Turnover continues at SAC Capital Advisors.
lead_paragraph: It may seem as though David Einhorn, the outspoken hedge fund manager, wants to have his cake and eat it, too. After an anonymous blogger on the website Seeking Alpha leaked one of his firm’s investments — a stake in Micron Technology — Mr. Einhorn’s firm, Greenlight Capital, asked a court to force the website to identify the writer by name. If Mr. Einhorn — a longtime champion of transparency when he singles out companies and other market participants — were to win, the result could limit the free flow of information to traditional news outlets and require sites like Seeking Alpha to not publish anonymous contributions, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: Letter From Nakamoto on Bitcoin Claim
abstract: “I did not create, invent or otherwise work on Bitcoin,” Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto said. “I unconditionally deny the Newsweek report.”
lead_paragraph: “I did not create, invent or otherwise work on Bitcoin,” Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto said. “I unconditionally deny the Newsweek report.”

headline: Putative Bitcoin Founder Categorically Denies It
abstract: Dorian Nakamoto appeared to be laying the groundwork for a lawsuit against Newsweek, saying its article had harmed him. He stopped short of saying he would sue.
lead_paragraph: Around 10 days after being identified by Newsweek magazine as the mysterious creator of the digital currency Bitcoin, Dorian Nakamoto, a 64-year-old semi-employed engineer, has hired a lawyer and issued a statement unconditionally denying that he had any involvement in Bitcoin.

headline: Alibaba’s New York State of Mind
abstract: Alibaba confirms it will begin the process of going public in New York. | Vodafone agrees to purchase the Spanish cable company Ono. | Investors are waiting to see the extent of Western sanctions on Russia after Crimea’s vote to secede from Ukraine. | The Justice Department put investigations of mortgage crime on the back burner.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, China’s online commerce giant, says it plans to begin the process of going public in New York, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The long-awaited initial public offering could be one of the biggest ever and could eventually raise more than the $16 billion that Facebook secured nearly two years ago. Analysts estimate that Alibaba could reach a valuation upward of $130 billion.

headline: The Threats That Help PayPal
abstract: EBay’s PayPal is innovating fast, spurred by threats from several directions.
lead_paragraph: The best thing that happened to PayPal in years may also be why it has turned into a Wall Street football: a big upswing in innovation, fed by the prospect of irrelevance.

headline: Start-Up Seeks to Capitalize on Security Concerns for Bitcoins
abstract: Xapo, a start-up from a tech entrepreneur promises security, backed by an insurer, to store Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: After living with hyperinflation, currency fluctuations and minimal access to credit in his country, Wences Casares, an Argentine raised on a sheep farm, says he has the vision and team to make Bitcoin more widespread and accepted worldwide.

headline: S.E.C. Takes Aim at Another Former SAC Employee
abstract: The S.E.C. unveiled a civil case against a 10th former SAC Capital employee. | An internal investigation found that the Justice Department had repeatedly and significantly overstated its efforts to prosecute mortgage fraud. | G.E. filed to spin off its North American retail finance unit in an initial public offering. | Lions Gate agreed to admit to wrongdoing and pay a $7.5 million fine for failing to disclose how it stopped a takeover by Carl C. Icahn in 2010.
lead_paragraph: S.E.C. TAKES AIM AT 10TH FORMER SAC EMPLOYEE  |  The Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, isn’t done just yet. Federal regulators announced on Thursday a civil case against Ronald N. Dennis, who worked for SAC for less than two years, for prompting a number of illegal trades stemming from confidential tips he received about two technology companies, Dell and Foundry Networks, Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Dennis, the 10th former employee of SAC to face civil or criminal insider trading charges, settled with the S.E.C., agreeing to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000.

headline: China Puts a Stop to Plans for Virtual Credit Cards
abstract: China’s central bank said it wanted to assess the risks that customers could face using the untested services from the online giants Alibaba and Tencent.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s central bank has ordered the Internet giants Alibaba and Tencent to halt plans to issue virtual credit cards in partnership with a large Chinese bank, citing concern over safety risks.

headline: Corrections: March 14, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Today in Small Business: Clueless Sales Representatives
abstract: Why celebrities are entering the wine business. And how to manage a budget.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Today in Small Business: Yelp Gets Negative Reviews
abstract: The president looks to expand overtime pay. Getting customer feedback. Google’s first retail store. And Disney’s ultimate tweet.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: A Look at Citi’s Challenges in Mexico
abstract: Citigroup’s troubles in Mexico illustrate the challenges of emerging markets. | No mention of its founder in Men’s Wearhouse’s deal announcement. | SAC Capital Advisors gets a new name. | Herbalife shares fell after William A. Ackman accused the company of “operating illegally” in China.
lead_paragraph: In the financial crisis year of 2008, Citigroup severed ties to Mexican companies that it feared could imperil its Mexican affiliate, but it seems that those efforts did not go far enough, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. A $400 million fraud at Citigroup’s Banamex unit that was discovered last month highlights the limitations of that kind of culling, and underscores the challenges of finding solid lending clients in a country where the line between big business and political cronyism can become blurred.

headline: A Turnaround for Bitcoin at SXSW
abstract: For Bitcoin entrepreneurs, the rise from scrappy outsiders to tech world insiders has been a bit dizzying.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — At last year’s South by Southwest gathering, regarded as the place where are the hip technology companies showed up, Bitcoin was still such an underdog that it was not important enough to command a single event or panel.

headline: Will the Real Satoshi Nakamoto Please Stand Up?
abstract: Particularly in Japan, those named Satoshi Nakamoto have been garnering a lot of attention as the search continues for the creator of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Satoshi Nakamoto of Fujisawa, Japan, is a shoe repairman.

headline: Virtual Exchange Plans Are Sought in New York
abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, the superintendent of New York’s Department of Financial Services, issued his first public order on virtual currencies like Bitcoin, calling for proposals for creating regulated exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | At a time when some government agencies are backing away from virtual currency, New York’s top financial regulator is taking a big step forward.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation Bolsters Its Ranks
abstract: Jim Harper of the Cato Institute will act as government liaison, as regulators struggle with how to oversee the evolving world of digital currency. Amy Weiss, a former White House deputy press secretary, was also brought on as an outside consultant.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin Foundation is adding to its ranks as regulators around the world struggle with how to oversee the evolving world of digital currency.

headline: Icahn’s Fight Against eBay
abstract: Marc Andreessen has become a target of Carl C. Icahn. | Positive News for Puerto Rico on the sale of roughly $3 billion in bonds. | Chiquita to become the king of bananas with a deal for an Irish fruit company. | The Blackstone Group and TPG Capital are said to be joining forces in a bid for Gates Global.
lead_paragraph: Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor, has recently been caught in the verbal cross hairs of the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The war of words stems from Mr. Icahn’s campaign to pressure eBay, the online auction company, to spin off its electronic payment unit PayPal. Among other things, he has accused Mr. Andreessen, an eBay board member, of various conflicts of interest that affected eBay’s sale of Skype in 2009 for $2.75 billion to a group of investors that included Mr. Andreessen’s venture capital firm.

headline: At SXSW Conference, a Mother Presses Her Son’s Case
abstract: Ross Ulbricht was arrested in October and charged with operating the Silk Road, the online drug bazaar where Bitcoin was the only money accepted. His mother, Lyn, hopes that the crowd at SXSW would be receptive to her son’s cause.
lead_paragraph: Among the tech start-ups pitching their ideas at SXSW this week, there was a mother, advocating not a new company but the cause of her son.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Calls Bitcoin ‘Surreal’
abstract: James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, said in a television interview on Monday that he did not have a firm grasp of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: To its devotees, Bitcoin represents the future of transactions. But the financial establishment is still scratching its head over the virtual currency.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Stars of Vine
abstract: Financiers opening sweet shops. A Colorado entrepreneur sells marijuana-infused products. The buying power of people older than 50.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Ackman’s Battle to Bring Down Herbalife
abstract: William A. Ackman and his lobbying effort to bring down Herbalife. | Documents point to mortgage lapses at Credit Suisse. | A judge rules against R.B.C. over the lender’s advice in a 2011 buyout. | Bankers go to great lengths to get credit for deals, even if they did not advise on them.
lead_paragraph: After staking $1 billion on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, William A. Ackman’s activist hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, has been lobbying aggressively to bring it down, Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson write in The New York Times. Others have criticized the business practices of Herbalife, which sells vitamins and other supplements through independent distributors, but Mr. Ackman’s attack is “unprecedented in its scale,” they write. For its part, Herbalife continues to strongly deny his accusations that the company is a pyramid scheme.

headline: Newsweek Returns to Print and Sets Off a Bitcoin Storm
abstract: The magazine’s story claiming to have uncovered the founder of the digital currency drew a wave of attention, much of it negative.
lead_paragraph: After being out of print for 14 months, Newsweek wanted its return to the newsstands to land with a splash. So it put out an issue with a darkened cover featuring a theatrical silver mask, and made an explosive claim: It had uncovered the mysterious founder of the digital currency Bitcoin.

headline: Art Matters | At the Independent Art Fair, Thinking Outside the White Box
abstract: The fifth edition of the alternative show offers an intimate scale and collaborative environment.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Dee and Darren Flook founded the Independent Art Fair in 2010, the art landscape in New York was a different place. Frieze had yet to enter the American market, and the vast Armory Show dominated the fair scene. “There was really a need for something more than the model that was imposed on us,” says the fair’s director, Laura Mitterrand.

headline: Bitcoin's Purported Founder Speaks Out
abstract: Newsweek reported that Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto was the founder of the digital currency Bitcoin. But Mr. Nakamoto denied the claim in an exclusive interview with The Associated Press.
lead_paragraph: Newsweek reported that Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto was the founder of the digital currency Bitcoin. But Mr. Nakamoto denied the claim in an exclusive interview with The Associated Press.

headline: Alleged Bitcoin founder denies involvement
abstract: A reclusive Japanese American suspected being the 'father' of Bitcoin emerged from his California home, denies any involvement with the digital currency. Gavino Garay reports.
lead_paragraph: A reclusive Japanese American suspected being the 'father' of Bitcoin emerged from his California home, denies any involvement with the digital currency. Gavino Garay reports.

abstract: Also on the Minute, intrigue over the inventor of Bitcoin and Plácido Domingo makes a second career as a baritone.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, intrigue over the inventor of Bitcoin and Plácido Domingo makes a second career as a baritone.

headline: Cerberus and Safeway Strike $9 Billion Deal
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management agreed to acquire Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion. | A Newsweek article claims to have unmasked the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many remain unconvinced. | Four former leaders at the once-mighty law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf were charged by New York prosecutors with larceny and securities fraud. | S.E.C. employees are likely to be no better at trading stocks than the rest of us, the Deal Professor says.
lead_paragraph: SUPER DEAL: CERBERUS TO BUY SAFEWAY FOR $9 BILLION  |  In one of the largest leveraged buyouts since the financial crisis, a group led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to acquire Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion, Michael J. de la Merced and William Alden write in DealBook. The deal, which will be financed by $7.6 billion worth of borrowed money, is the biggest leveraged buyout so far this year. Cerberus plans to merge Safeway with Albertsons, a smaller grocery store chain that it owns.

headline: Daily Report: Mystery Swirls Around Unmasking of Bitcoin Inventor
abstract: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: Central to Bitcoin’s cachet has been the mythic status of the system’s creator, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams report. Its developer went by the name Satoshi Nakamoto, but that is all that Bitcoin’s adopters seemed to know — or wanted to know. After all, Bitcoin was a project dedicated in part to making it easier to avoid the all-seeing gaze of the government and corporate America.

headline: Japan Won’t Impose Banking Laws on Bitcoin
abstract: The government of Japan released a six-page paper stating that Bitcoin is a commodity, not a currency, and will be subject to taxes but not regulations.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Bitcoin trading platforms can, for now, operate freely under Japanese law, the government said Friday in a note that signaled a hands-off approach to the virtual currency.

headline: Bitcoin’s Mysterious Creator Is Said to Be Identified
abstract: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:31 p.m. | Even as it has grown into a new type of digital money worth billions of dollars, Bitcoin has always retained an air of mystery.

headline: Bitcoin Is a Protocol. Bitcoin Is a Brand.
abstract: The existence of Internet-based currencies following in the wake of Bitcoin says a lot about what makes the new kind of money successful, and points to a hazard common to open-source software.
lead_paragraph: Updated with additional reporting. | So it appears the creator of Bitcoin may not have been a young Japanese mathematical wizard as had been long rumored. Instead, as Newsweek has first reported, he is believed to be a 64-year-old Japanese-American man named Satoshi Nakamoto who clearly does not care for attention.

headline: More Trouble For a Once-Mighty Law Firm
abstract: Three former executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf are expected to face criminal charges. | The Bank of England suspends a staff member in connection with a foreign exchange inquiry. | Paul Tudor Jones II is no longer seeing the mind-boggling returns he once did. | Cerberus’s deal for the Safeway grocery chain gets complicated.
lead_paragraph: Three former top executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the giant law firm that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2012, are expected to be charged on Thursday with misleading other lawyers and lenders about the financial health of the firm, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The details of the charges are still unclear, but two people said the lawyers might be accused of grand larceny.

headline: Daily Report: To Ensure a Secure Future, Bitcoin Might Need Oversight
abstract: Some backers of the digital currency are calling for human oversight to guard against more losses like the $470 million collapse of Mt. Gox.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a billion dollars has gone missing, and nobody knows how, Farhad Manjoo reports. Some say there was outright theft. Others suspect fraud. Many blame lax controls, poor oversight and, above all, a reckless, globe-spanning, Wild West culture — a culture that everyone agrees is ripe for wholesale reform.

headline: Corrections: March 6, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 6, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: For Bitcoin, Secure Future Might Need Oversight
abstract: Some backers of the digital currency are calling for human oversight to guard against more losses like the $470 million collapse of Mt. Gox.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a billion dollars has gone missing, and nobody knows how. Some say there was outright theft. Others suspect fraud. Many blame lax controls, poor oversight and, above all, a reckless, globe-spanning, Wild West culture — a culture that everyone agrees is ripe for wholesale reform.

headline: Plaintiffs in Suit Seek to Freeze Mt. Gox’s U.S. Assets
abstract: Plaintiffs in a class-action lawsuit filed a motion on Thursday seeking a temporary injunction to keep the bankrupt Bitcoin exchange and its chief executive, Mark Karpeles, from moving any money outside of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Customers of Mt. Gox are trying to freeze assets in the United States of the bankrupt Bitcoin exchange and its chief executive, Mark Karpeles.

headline: A Legal Standoff in the Madoff Case
abstract: A document sheds light on how a legal standoff has kept Bernard L. Madoff’s ties to JPMorgan’s shrouded in mystery. | Moelis & Company files for an I.P.O. | Wall Street’s latest hot thing could be appraisal rights. | The Supreme Court to hear arguments that could reshape securities fraud cases. | The website Silk Road had a digital outpost in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Even after five years, it is still unclear what exactly JPMorgan Chase bankers knew about Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme. A newly obtained government document does not provide the answer, but does shed some light on why the mystery remains, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The document reveals that JPMorgan and federal regulators fought over access to bank employee interviews, eventually pitting the Justice Department against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.

headline: Japan Said to Be Ready to Impose Bitcoin Rules
abstract: The new guidelines, which ban banks and securities firms from handling Bitcoin, will reportedly treat Bitcoins as a commodity rather than a currency.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is drawing up a plan to regulate Bitcoin, officials said on Wednesday, including clauses the Nikkei business daily said would tax Bitcoin transactions and ban banks and securities firms from handling the digital currency.

headline: Silk Road, Shut Down in Fall, Had Digital Outpost in Pennsylvania
abstract: A staff member of Lafayette College in Pennsylvania played a small role in the investigation that resulted in the shutdown of Silk Road, the online marketplace where drugs and weapons could be bought with Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: A staff member in the electrical engineering department of a liberal arts college in eastern Pennsylvania played a small role in the investigation that resulted in the shutdown last fall of Silk Road, the online marketplace where drugs and weapons could be bought with Bitcoin.

headline: Today in Small Business: Kitchen Incubators
abstract: What to ask a potential buyer of your business. And entrepreneurs to follow on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: A Calming of Global Markets
abstract: Market tensions ease after Russia appears to back away from further action in Ukraine. | A Citigroup affiliate in Los Angeles receives a federal subpoena. | A small-business owner continues his battle against U.S. Bancorp. | Men’s Wearhouse and Jos. A. Bank reach a nondisclosure accord, paving the way for a merger.
lead_paragraph: GLOBAL MARKETS RISE AFTER UKRAINE TENSIONS COOL  |  Global markets calmed on Tuesday after Russia appeared to back away from further action in Ukraine, with President Vladimir V. Putin calling an end to a military exercise he ordered last week. The crisis in Ukraine had caused turmoil in the global financial markets on Monday, hitting stocks and driving up energy prices. Analysts maintained that there was little risk of damage to Western economies, but the rising tension nevertheless unsettled investors, who were already concerned about emerging markets, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Corrections: March 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 4, 2014
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Bitcoin Loss Highlights Elusive Paths of Regulation
abstract: The collapse of Mt. Gox and the loss of $450 million in Bitcoins is pushing governments to enhance regulation of virtual currencies, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Can nearly $450 million go missing without a crime taking place? That is only one of the questions stemming from the collapse of the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox that present a host of challenges for governments worldwide that are struggling to regulate virtual currencies.

headline: Britain Drops Plan to Tax Trading of Bitcoins
abstract: Britain’s tax agency said on Monday that it would not charge a 20 percent tax, known as a value added tax, or VAT, on trades of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British tax authorities said on Monday that they would not impose a tax on trading of the virtual currency Bitcoin.

headline: A Record Profit for Berkshire
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway posted a record profit in 2013. | Tensions in Ukraine rattle global financial markets. | A Mexican unit of Citigroup was defrauded of as much as $400 million. | A JPMorgan Chase shareholder has introduced a proposal to break up the bank. | Mt. Gox and a steady erosion of faith in the Bitcoin community.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren E. Buffett, released its annual report on Saturday, disclosing a record profit in 2013 of $19.5 billion, a 32 percent increase from $14.8 billion in 2012. Berkshire’s book value per share — the measure Mr. Buffett uses to assess the company’s performance — rose 18.2 percent in 2013, much less than the 32.4 percent rise in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. But even as Berkshire posts handsome results, it remains to be seen whether it can continue to make large acquisitions that will help it sustain its reputation as the nation’s savviest investor, Peter Eavis and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 28, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses pension reform and Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Cities and states across the country are grappling with how to pay for pensions and retiree health care costs. In New Jersey, Chris Christie is proposing a $34.4 billion budget that includes more than $2 billion in pension payments, the largest outlay yet to shore up a retirement plan for public workers that the governor calls a “looming crisis.” This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss why cities and states are facing pension crises and what they can do to solve the problem.

headline: In Search of a Stable Electronic Currency
abstract: Bitcoin has fluctuated wildly in value, but it could indirectly point the way toward a system of better pricing and risk management.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin, an experiment with a radically new kind of electronic money, has exhibited many of the characteristics of a speculative bubble. That was clear long before the collapse of the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox last week.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, March. 2
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “Mt. Gox is in the past, and the brightest minds in the room are hard at work building a responsible and secure future.”

headline: The Bitcoin Blasphemy
abstract: Created to avoid government, the virtual currency won’t survive without it.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I read a story about bitcoin, the virtual currency that has been so much in the news these days, I think about a man named Dee Hock. In the early 1970s, Hock created the credit card system that we now know as Visa. Hock was a man who liked to think grandiose thoughts. When it came to Visa, and credit cards in general, Hock used to describe them not just as a way to get a short-term loan but as a new kind of payment system, an exchange of value that was on par with, and that competed with, cash.

headline: Fortress Discloses a Paper Loss on Bitcoin
abstract: The Fortress Investment Group is the first large public company to disclose a stake in Bitcoin. It had an unrealized loss of $3.7 million at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Fortress Investment Group reported a paper loss of $3.7 million from investments in Bitcoin, the first large public company to disclose a stake in the volatile virtual currency.

headline: Daily Report: Mt. Gox, Having Lost Essentially All Bitcoins, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
lead_paragraph: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins, essentially all of them, in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo.

headline: The Demise of Mt. Gox
abstract: Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday. | Jos. A. Bank rejected Men’s Wearhouse’s latest bid, but agreed to meet with its larger rival. | Ocwen Financial and its chairman are under fire from regulators and investors. | Janet L. Yellen acknowledged at a Senate hearing that the cold weather had contributed to the recent run of disappointing economic data. | A British regulator is pursuing charges against a third person for influencing Libor.
lead_paragraph: MT. GOX FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY  |  As feared, Mt. Gox, the troubled exchange for the virtual currency Bitcoin, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack, Hiroko Tabuchi writes in DealBook. The Tokyo-based exchange halted trading earlier this week.

headline: Erosion of Faith Was Death Knell for Mt. Gox
abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
lead_paragraph: As the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox was careening toward collapse in early February, its owner, Mark Karpeles, found that even some of his fellow virtual currency advocates were losing faith.

headline: Blind evangelism next big threat to bitcoin after Gox bust
abstract: Stung by the collapse of once dominant exchange Mt. Gox, bitcoin early-adopters remain convinced. But spinning the loss as a positive outcome won't help the crypto-currency win what it now needs most. Jon Gordon reports.
lead_paragraph: Stung by the collapse of once dominant exchange Mt. Gox, bitcoin early-adopters remain convinced. But spinning the loss as a positive outcome won't help the crypto-currency win what it now needs most. Jon Gordon reports.

headline: Credit Suisse Under Scrutiny
abstract: A Senate panel criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday for helping American clients hide billion in assets. | R.B.S. reported a $15 billion net loss for 2013. | Authorities across the globe are moving to regulate Bitcoin after the collapse of Mt. Gox. | Ocwen faces scrutiny over potential conflicts of interest. | Versace agrees to sell minority stake to Blackstone.
lead_paragraph: SENATE SCRUTINIZES CREDIT SUISSE OVER HIDDEN ASSETS  |  A Senate panel criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday, contending that the Swiss bank helped as many as 22,000 Americans hide an estimated $10 billion to $12 billion in assets from the United States tax authorities, Annie Lowrey writes in DealBook. The Senate hearing, the result of a two-year investigation into practices at the bank from 2001 through 2008, followed a scathing report issued on Tuesday by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that at times read like a legal thriller for its bizarre details on the lengths the bank went to aid Americans in tax evasion.

headline: Today in Small Business: Online Reviews Matter More Than Most Owners Think
abstract: Why content marketing is hot. A new invoicing tool. And business owners who can’t answer a simple question about their businesses may be in trouble.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today?

headline: Now, Nations Mull the Ways to Regulate Bitcoin
abstract: In the wake of the implosion of the Bitcoin trading platform Mt. Gox, countries like the United States and Japan are gathering data on virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Authorities around the world are grappling with how to regulate virtual currency in the wake of the implosion of Mt. Gox, a prominent trading platform for Bitcoin.

headline: A Silver Lining in Bitcoin’s Stumble
abstract: The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night stirred ire, but also hope for the virtual currency. | A Senate report says Credit Suisse helped American clients hide billions in assets. | Bank of America is facing two new investigations. | Argentina is asking the United States Supreme Court to throw out a lower-court ruling on its debt.
lead_paragraph: BITCOIN’S SILVER LINING  |  The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night naturally stirred outrage and panic. After all, a document circulating widely in the Bitcoin world said the company had lost 744,000 Bitcoins — about 6 percent of Bitcoins in circulation — worth more than $300 million at current exchange rates. But Bitcoin’s latest troubles did little to shake the confidence of many, and indeed, the virtual currency’s stumble may provide just the spark it needs to become a more mature part of the financial system, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline: Daily Report: As Mt. Gox Falls, Bitcoin Looks to the Future
abstract: Ire over the apparent collapse of one of the earliest online marketplaces for the virtual currency was paired with hope that it could lead to a maturation of virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market, Rachel Abrams and Nathaniel Popper report.

headline: Trading Site Failure Stirs Ire and Hope for Bitcoin
abstract: With one of its earliest marketplaces gone, the world of virtual currency may have to to become a more mature part of the financial system.
lead_paragraph: The apparent collapse of Bitcoin’s best-known and once-dominant trading platform has provoked outrage among its users, but it has also stirred hopes that the way may now be clear for more established players to transform and rein in a largely unregulated market.

headline: Chief of SecondMarket on Bitcoin
abstract: CNBC interviews Barry Silbert, the chief executive of SecondMarket, on the closure of Mt. Gox and his plan to open a Bitcoin exchange in the United States.
lead_paragraph: CNBC interviews Barry Silbert, the chief executive of SecondMarket, on the closure of Mt. Gox and his plan to open a Bitcoin exchange in the United States.

headline: Digital doubts after Bitcoin debacle
abstract: After Mt. Gox, once the world's biggest bitcoin exchange, ceased trading Tuesday, the future of the digital currency is up for debate. Bobbi Rebell reports.
lead_paragraph: After Mt. Gox, once the world's biggest bitcoin exchange, ceased trading Tuesday, the future of the digital currency is up for debate. Bobbi Rebell reports.

headline: Digital doubts after Bitcoin debacle
abstract: After Mt. Gox, once the world's biggest bitcoin exchange, ceased trading Tuesday, the future of the digital currency is up for debate. Bobbi Rebell reports.
lead_paragraph: After Mt. Gox, once the world's biggest bitcoin exchange, ceased trading Tuesday, the future of the digital currency is up for debate. Bobbi Rebell reports.

headline: Choose Your Monetary Adventure, Mt. Gox Edition
abstract: The bandit factor.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin was, of course, created in part to cater to libertarian dreams – to provide a way to store your wealth where governments can’t steal it through taxation or currency debasement.

headline: No Bailout for Bitcoin Holders
abstract: The distance from the official world is great enough that Mt. Gox customers are almost totally on their own, writes Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that the leading stockbroker in a country closed its doors without giving any reason. Its clients would be in a panic and customers of rival firms would be very nervous. That is exactly what has happened to Bitcoin, the leading pseudo-currency.

headline: Defending Bitcoin, Andreessen Says Mt. Gox Is ‘Like MF Global’
abstract: Marc Andreessen, whose firm has invested millions of dollars in Bitcoin-related start-ups, portrayed the apparent collapse of the Mt. Gox exchange as an isolated problem, but his comparison to MF Global struck some observers as less than comforting.
lead_paragraph: The apparent collapse on Monday of Mt. Gox, the most prominent exchange for Bitcoin, spooked many holders of the virtual currency, as they tried to determine whether the problems pointed to larger flaws in the Bitcoin system.

headline: Will People Get Their Bitcoins Back?
abstract: Garrick Hileman, an economic historian at the London School of Economics, discusses on CNBC the potential impact on Bitcoin by the disappearance of the Mt. Gox exchange.
lead_paragraph: Garrick Hileman, an economic historian at the London School of Economics, discusses on CNBC the potential impact on Bitcoin by the disappearance of the Mt. Gox exchange.

headline: Protests after bitcoin exchange disappears
abstract: Protesters have gathered outside of the former office of troubled Tokyo-based Mt. Gox bitcoin exchange after they were unable to access their funds. Melanie Ralph reports
lead_paragraph: Protesters have gathered outside of the former office of troubled Tokyo-based Mt. Gox bitcoin exchange after they were unable to access their funds. Melanie Ralph reports

headline: Protests after bitcoin exchange disappears
abstract: Protesters gathered outside of the troubled Tokyo-based Mt. Gox bitcoin exchange office on Tuesday after they were unable to access their funds, showing how risky investment in the digital currency can be.
lead_paragraph: Protesters gathered outside of the troubled Tokyo-based Mt. Gox bitcoin exchange office on Tuesday after they were unable to access their funds, showing how risky investment in the digital currency can be.

headline: @GSElevator’s Big Reveal
abstract: The identity of the person behind the Twitter account @GSElevator, long though to be a Goldman Sachs employee, is actually a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas. | The Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox is on the verge of collapse. | U.S. and British authorities unite against rate-rigging. | Pension funds sue a hedge fund manager on a deal gone cold. | Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg thinks WhatsApp deal was a steal.
lead_paragraph: @GSELEVATOR EXPOSED  |  For three years, Wall Street has been trying to identify the employee behind the Twitter account @GSElevator, which reported anonymous snippets purportedly overheard in elevators at Goldman Sachs. But it turns out, the tweeter doesn’t work at Goldman and never did, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. In fact, the tweeter is a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas named John LeFevre.

headline: Daily Report: Bitcoin World Is Shaken by Apparent Theft at Exchange
abstract: Mt. Gox, a prominent Bitcoin exchange, was said to be on the verge of collapse following a major theft, even as another company announced plans for a virtual currency market.
lead_paragraph: The most prominent Bitcoin exchange appeared to be on the verge of collapse late Monday, raising questions about the future of a volatile marketplace, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams report.

headline: Apparent Theft at Mt. Gox Shakes Bitcoin World
abstract: The prominent Bitcoin exchange was said to be on the verge of total collapse following a major theft, even as another company announced plans for a high-profile virtual currency market.
lead_paragraph: The most prominent Bitcoin exchange appeared to be on the verge of collapse late Monday, raising questions about the future of a volatile marketplace.

headline: Facebook Stock Not So Different Than Bitcoin
abstract: The risk for Facebook and Bitcoin, respectively, is that someone creates a better social network or decentralized digital currency, writes Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: With its extraordinary swoop on WhatsApp last week, Facebook proved its stock is not so different from the crypto-currency of the moment, Bitcoin. They can both be used for certain, specific purposes. Neither is backed by a government. Both depend on vast networks of individuals. And their worth reflects demand, which is based on murky fundamentals. The trick: monetize them while they still have value.

headline: Chief of Mt. Gox Resigns From Bitcoin Foundation
abstract: The resignation is the latest blow to Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, and the virtual currency, which has encountered several technical problems recently.
lead_paragraph: Mark Karpeles, the chief executive of Mt. Gox, once the world’s largest Bitcoin exchange, has resigned from the board of the Bitcoin Foundation.

headline: A Clearer Picture on Lehman’s Collapse
abstract: Federal Reserve transcripts released on Friday provide the fullest picture yet of the thinking of top government officials on Lehman’s implosion in 2008. | Facebook’s deal for WhatsApp, which could be worth up to $19 billion, is all about the address book. | Greater pension fund disclosure may have helped Detroit avoid bankruptcy. | Comcast and Netflix strike a deal on service.
lead_paragraph: LEHMAN REVISITED  |  The Federal Reserve let Lehman Brothers fail more than five years ago. But it wasn’t until Friday that the Fed released transcripts of the 2008 meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee that provide the fullest picture yet of the thinking of top government officials on Lehman’s collapse, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook.

headline: Google, Riding Off Into the Sunset
abstract: There is so much hype around new technologies, it is difficult to distinguish between what might exist real soon and what will only be real eventually or never. Case in point: the driverless car.
lead_paragraph: Cabbies and limo drivers have so much to think about. Should they ally themselves with Uber or Lyft or Sidecar or someone else promising to revolutionize ground transportation? If they do, will they be insured if they get in an accident while working with their own car? And what of the future? Will they be replaced by a fleet of driverless cars, a technology that has been talked about so much it seems just around the corner?

headline: Weekend Reading: Which Technology Pundit Are You?
abstract: Facebook’s $16 billion bid for the text messaging application WhatsApp has captured everyone’s attention. With apologies to Buzzfeed, this is what your opinion of the deal says about you.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s $16 billion bid for the text messaging application WhatsApp has captured everyone’s attention. Is it a sign that the tech bubble is about to burst or is it a savvy move to cement the future of the social media giant?

headline: Tech’s New Feeding Frenzy
abstract: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C. regulations. | Banker go-to GrubHub Seamless files for an I.P.O. | The Fed finds vitriol among Wall Street’s financiers.
lead_paragraph: TECH’S NEW FEEDING FRENZY  |  As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebook’s fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). “Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly — and with such conviction — to avoid being left behind,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

headline: Facebook’s $16 Billion Deal for WhatsApp
abstract: Facebook scoops up WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million global users, for at least $16 billion in cash and stock. | The supermarket chain Safeway is exploring a sale of the company to private equity. | Harvard lands its largest gift ever, $150 million, from the hedge fund founder Kenneth C. Griffin. | The Winklevoss twins create a financial index called the Winkdex that will provide a regularly updated figure for the price of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: BIG DEAL: FACEBOOK BUYS WHATSAPP FOR $16 BILLION  |  When Facebook offered to buy Snapchat last year for $3 billion, the messaging app turned Facebook down. So this time, Facebook made it harder for its target to say no. On Wednesday, Facebook announced it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging application with 450 million users, for at least $16 billion in cash and stock, its largest acquisition by far and one that represents a new height in the frenzy to acquire popular technology start-ups, David Gelles and Vindu Goel write in DealBook.

headline: Winklevoss Brothers Offer an Index to Track Price of Bitcoin
abstract: Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, famous for their legal battle with the Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, have created a financial index that provides a regularly updated figure for the price of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:03 p.m. | Stock traders have the Standard & Poor’s 500. Bitcoin bettors will have the Winkdex.

headline: Doubts About Candy Crush’s Sweetness
abstract: Candy Crush’s meteoric rise has raised fears of a bubble following the I.P.O. filing of its parent, King Digital Entertainment. | Few firms have been as aggressive as the Blackstone Group in searching for lucrative deals in Ireland. | Homeowners trying to avert foreclosure are confronting problems on a new front. | It may be time to call a truce on the Wall Street bias in looking at executive compensation.
lead_paragraph: SUGAR RUSH FOR CANDY CRUSH  |  King Digital Entertainment’s filing of a $500 million initial public offering on Tuesday had many investors salivating. But it remains to be seen whether the company behind the addictive game Candy Crush can sustain its sweetness and avoid the pitfalls of other game makers, Jenna Wortham and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Indeed, Candy Crush attracts 93 million players each day and accounts for nearly 80 percent of the company’s revenue, which neared $1.9 billion by the end of 2013 from $164 million in 2012.

headline: A $25 Billion Deal for Drug Makers
abstract: The drug maker Actavis will acquire Forest Laboratories for about $25 billion. | King Digital Entertainment, the maker of Candy Crush Saga, has filed for an I.P.O. | Bitcoin is experiencing some growing pains. | Britain’s Serious Fraud Office has begun criminal proceedings against three former Barclays employees suspected in the manipulation of Libor. | Comcast’s proposed deal for Time Warner Cable could set off a frenzy of deal-making.
lead_paragraph: DRUG MAKERS ANNOUNCE $25 BILLION DEAL  |  Actavis, the world’s second-largest generic drug maker by market value, will acquire Forest Laboratories for about $25 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday. The deal is a coup for the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who gained a seat on the board of Forest Labs in 2012 and is one of the company’s largest shareholders, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Regulators and Hackers Put Bitcoin to the Test
abstract: The virtual currency’s meteoric rise encountered stormy weather that could determine its future.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is facing significant growing pains as it struggles to move beyond a stormy adolescence.

headline: Weekend Reading: Cable Deals and JPMorgan Hiring
abstract: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: A Twist in Charter’s Pursuit of a Cable Deal
abstract: Charter Communications has played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating a full slate of directors to its target’s board. | Federal prosecutors have filed actions against businesses that buy luxury cars at domestic dealerships and then send them to China. | The S.E.C. may have helped create the problem it is now hoping to solve. | Janet L. Yellen set a familiar direction for the Fed in her first public remarks before Congress on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: CHARTER’S BID FOR TIME WARNER CABLE HEATS UP  |  Charter Communications on Tuesday played its latest move in its pursuit of Time Warner Cable, nominating 13 directors to its target’s board. Now, as Time Warner Cable’s annual meeting approaches, shareholders will have to decide whether they want to force in a new board that would be more receptive to a deal with Charter, David Gelles writes in DealBook. Charter proposed to acquire Time Warner Cable for $132.50 a share last month, but Time Warner Cable maintains that Charter’s bid undervalues the cable operator.

headline: Liquid-Cooled Supercomputers, to Trim the Power Bill
abstract: Looking to reduce energy bills and environmental strains, operators of supercomputers are immersing them in cooling liquids.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dropping a home computer into a vat of liquid would wreck it.

headline: Today in Small Business: Million-Dollar Tweets

headline: Daily Report: Software Error Shakes Bitcoin Exchange

And then, almost on cue, a highly publicized case study arrived courtesy of Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, Mr. Sorkin writes in this week’s DealBook column.

headline: Exchange crash reveals bitcoin's real-world weakness
abstract: Yet another mini-crisis for the bitcoin cryptocurrency shows the market is still shallow, and that it has a long way to go before it can truly secure a place as a global payment alternative. Jon Gordon reports.

headline: A Chinese Official’s Job Plea to JPMorgan’s Chief

Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, remains as elusive as ever. | Alibaba seeks control of AutoNavi. | Apple gains an ally in the fight against Carl C. Icahn. | Stealth I.P.O.’s are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: CHINESE OFFICIAL MADE JOB PLEA TO JPMORGAN’S CHIEF  |  In yet another potential setback for JPMorgan Chase, a confidential email shows a top Chinese insurance regulator directly asked Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan’s chairman and chief executive, for a “favor” to hire a young job applicant, a family friend of the regulator. Interviews, and the previously unreported email, show that Mr. Dimon met the applicant at a meeting in 2012, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The meeting came as JPMorgan was seeking lucrative work from Chinese insurance companies.

lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — PEOPLE like to complain about banks popping up like Starbucks on every corner these days. But in poor neighborhoods, the phenomenon is quite the opposite: Over the past couple of decades, the banks have pulled out.

headline: Rewards Program Tries Bitcoin
abstract: The travel rewards website PointsHound is now including the virtual currency Bitcoin as a payout option.
lead_paragraph: PointsHound, a website that rewards travel reservations with frequent-flier miles and hotel points, is using the virtual currency Bitcoinin its payout system.

headline: A Guilty Verdict for Former SAC Trader
abstract: Mathew Martoma, the former trader at SAC Capital Advisors, was convicted of insider trading. | Mr. Martoma’s handling of a years-old episode involving fabrication of documents cast doubt on his trustworthiness and may have hindered a deal with prosecutors. | Legal troubles are doing little to stem a Bitcoin leader’s exuberance. | Apple buys $14 billion of its own shares.
lead_paragraph: FORMER SAC TRADER CONVICTED OF INSIDER TRADING  |  A federal jury in Manhattan found Mathew Martoma guilty on Thursday of insider trading , culminating a case that prosecutors had never thought would go to trial in the first place. The case may be the last criminal case to emerge from a decade-long investigation of Steven A. Cohen and his SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Martoma, who is married and has three young children, is expected to face a prison sentence of seven to 10 years.

headline: Legal Troubles Barely Subdue a Bitcoin Evangelist’s Sermons
abstract: Charles Shrem, the Bitcoin enthusiast, says he hopes one day to return to the world of the virtual currency, maybe as its chief aficianado.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before his arrest at Kennedy Airport, Charles Shrem was standing behind the Manhattan bar he invested in with some of his Bitcoin fortune, buzzing about his big plans for the virtual currency and himself.

headline: A Shrug at Puerto Rico’s Debt Downgrade
abstract: The markets barely responded to a downgrade of Puerto Rico’s credit rating. | The jury in the insider-trading trial of a former SAC manager seeks to review transcripts. | The currency trading industry is in flux. | A.I.G. is seeking to delay the $8.5 billion Bank of America mortgage settlement.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s lowered Puerto Rico’s credit rating to junk status on Tuesday, but on Wednesday, the market responded with barely a flinch. While prices of some of the island’s bonds traded lower, there was nothing close to the kind of mass sell-off that might indicate a panic, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook.

headline: Apple Takes Down a Bitcoin App
abstract: The app, named BlockChain, was one of the last remaining iPhone mobile applications that allowed users to buy and sell Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Apple has taken down one of the last remaining iPhone mobile applications that allowed users to buy and sell Bitcoin.

headline: New York Today: A Treacherous Wintry Mix
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: snow, sleet and rain make for nightmares on the roads, rails and sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:09 p.m.

headline: Hold the Apologies
abstract: The “Apology Watch” begins on the DealBook website. | A crowded courtroom heard closing arguments in the insider trading trial of a former SAC manager. | In Detroit bankruptcy, it is Wall Street vs. Main Street. | Stocks slumped Monday on disappointing economic data.
lead_paragraph: “What does saying ‘sorry’ mean when it’s tossed around with the frequency of a Justin Bieber scandal?” asks Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column. Almost every day, some prominent figure — a chief executive, a politician, an athlete — is apologizing for something — to say nothing of the average person. Are we in the midst of an apology crisis? To hear Dov Seidman talk about it, the answer is an emphatic yes. And in fact, Mr. Seidman is so sure that our mea culpas have become meaningless that he called for an “apology cease-fire” in front of several dozen chief executives and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: More Bitcoin Regulation Is Inevitable
abstract: The question is not whether there will be greater regulation of nongovernment currencies, but how much regulation they will face, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:12 p.m. |

headline: SAC Fashioning a New Identity
abstract: SAC Capital Advisors will soon fade to black. | An unlikely alliance looks to check the power of activist investors. | Jos. A. Bank weighs a deal for Eddie Bauer. | Private equity is playing a major role in the defense industry.
lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund started by Steven A. Cohen, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it. The firm, whose reputation is now intricately linked to an insider trading scandal, is in the midst of rebranding itself, including changing its name and corporate structure. And recently, a major bank distanced itself from the firm. Together, these developments provide the most vivid illustration yet of SAC’s steep fall from powerful hedge fund to marginalized player,  Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

headline: Weekend Reading: Super Bowl Quotes for Wall Street
abstract: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week we’re looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.
lead_paragraph: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week we’re looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.
